The vacuum assembled easily after getting it out of the box. (Be careful opening the box! My husband cut his finger following Dyson's 'how to open' instructions.)  My husband vacuumed the family room floor and I inspected the results.  The DC33 really didn't seem to be picking up much.  I have two cats, so when I vacuum I usually pick up a lot of cat hair.  My husband suggested that perhaps the floor wasn't that dirty?  I was sceptical.  So I got out my old DC17 and vacuumed over the same area the DC33 had just cleaned.  It was amazing how much dirt and cat hair the old vacuum picked up that the DC33 missed!  I don't know whether the old Dysons are more powerful than the new ones or whether the DC33 is just inferior to the DC17, but I decided the DC33 was not a keeper and returned it to Target the same day I purchased it.  I'm just going to keep my old Dyson awhile longer!

After reviewing several of the Dyson models and customer reviews, I decided on the full sized DC33 multi-surface model.  It truly does clean the carpets well.  As for the attachments, they were o.k.  Our house has several carpeted steps that need a little more than the flat surfaced attachment, so we will probably purchase one of the course bristled attachments.  I was AMAZED at how much dirt and dog hair it suctioned.  At first glance I was a bit apprehensive because it appeared to be very fragile and I break everything.  After putting it together (literally a few clicks 10 minutes) and NOT breaking it, looks like this vacume holds up well.  I vacumed everything I could think of, and for once I didn't have to worry about my vacume cleaner overheating and giving out on me.  The cord is extremely long so I didn't have to worry about having to unplug and plug as I vacumed.  The only bad thing (if you would even call it bad) is that in order to use the attachments, you have to remove the cord from the holders.  If that's the least of my worries, I'm in heaven.  This vacume was worth every penny!

Overall this vacuum is nice and light.  It has a very powerful suction even when the canister is close to full.  Not a lot of moving parts which is nice and simple to use.  Great to use for both carpet, tile, and wood flooring.  I would have rated this product 5 stars however, it does have some shortcomings.  It would be nice to easily access the brush so that hair and fabric can be easily pulled out.  The front of the vaccum is a bit tall which makes reaching under extended lower cabinets harder to reach, so you ended up having to pull the a accessory tool to reach these areas.  This isn't quite so effective when working with steps, you will need an attachment to vacuum really well.  Just using the vacuum alone on the steps makes it hard to maneuver and when the vacuum is near upright, it shifts some of the suction to the attachment tool.  For it's value and power, it is well worth it.  If you're looking at this product, you might want to check out Costco's version of the package though.  For a few more $$, you can have the same DC33 with the attachments already included.

If you are completely bald you should be fine. However, if you or anyone in your family has hair you are in for a real treat when it comes to removing hair from the beater brush. The beater brush bar is not removable. So, you'll get to sit on the floor, and cut and pull hair off the brush bar. This is not the clever engineering I expect from the Dyson company. Removing hair from the beater bar is something everyone needs to do to maintain a vaccum, and there's no easy way to do it with this model. Also, if you displace the belt while trying to clean the brush beater bar you are in for another round of horror trying to get the belt back in the right spot on the bar. So annyoing. The plastic parts holding the beater bar in place on each side are very fragile. It doesn't take much force at all to render your $400 vaccum useless by simply trying to remove hair from the brushbeater bar.There are lots of good things about it that others have mentioned here, but the beater bar issue is a deal breaker for me. Lesson learned.

I bought this as a replacement for my original yellow Dyson that I'd had since they first came out in the US.  I had been very happy with my first one.  Did a great job on carpets and bare floors and I have 3 Labs who shed.  I think the plastic housing on the back that holds the wand into the vacuum just wore out and snapped.  So, since you can't get replacement parts for that, I decided to buy a new one.  This new one is lighter in weight and shorter.  That's something I really appreciate being a petite woman.  Before lugging it to the second floor was a chore, now it's easy.  The cord is a bit shorter and the container that you empty a bit smaller but it works just as well as the original.  I'm very glad I bought it.  I also have a Miele that I use upstairs but it doesn't get the dog hair off the carpets the way this Dyson does.  I don't think there's any comparison there and I like not having to buy bags. For those people wondering if they need the animal model of a Dyson, I don't think it's necessary.  However, my dogs are short haired....maybe if you have a long-haired dog, the animal model is a better bet. Otherwise, get this one!

I have always tried to be a very clean person. vacuuming at least once or twice a week.Plus I purchased new carpet 2 years ago. The first time I ran the Dyson over a room that is not used very much I was amazed at how much dirt,  (not carpet fibers) can up. My first thought, ' I should have brought this a long time ago'. I get excited about using it. LOVE IT!

That is what it is supposed to do. This is very good product. It is so nice to see something designed by someone with a brain. Well thought out. Our floors have never been cleaner. I like the way you clean out the canister. You don't even have to touch anything, but the button!! No mess and no fuss.

Am I the only one that noticed that this thing didn't pick up EVERYTHING off their carpet?! It actually pushed some stuff around and didn't pick it up. It was a bird feather for crying out loud. There were bird seeds still left on the carpet.  I have many pets and hoped at this price I would be seeing some nice, clean carpets...but seriously, the cheapo ones I've had before picked up what the Dyson didn't!! I purchased this model from Lowes and thought it would be so awesome I even got the warranty.  Now I'm so sad that after the first use I didn't see anything special.  Oh, and don't even get me started on that weird wand.  It is going back to the store.

I purchased my DC33 this week and I am in love. I have two large dogs and a cat so there is no shortage of dander and fur on my hardwood floors and area rugs. I was worried about the wand based on other reviews, but have found that even though it is awkward to use, it has strong suction and cleans baseboards, windows, and small areas rather well. I used the wand to clean a couch in my house that I THOUGHT was clean and got two canisters of hair off of it. The long cord is a plus as well. I've been using a shop vac to clean my house for years and that four foot cord kept me agitated! The DC33 works on both the rugs and hard floor very well and I like that the head of the vacuum is flat so it goes right up against the walls getting all of the runaway balls of dogs hair. I love it! I did not purchase through Amazon. I chose to go to Bed, Bath and Beyond and use my 20% off coupon that comes in the mail. It says on the coupon that it is not good on Dyson products, but I did not have a hard time using the discount. The total with tax came to $340. Just a heads up if you are trying to save some money!

I bought the Dyson DC33 after reading all the reviews.  This is the best price for an incredible vacuum!  I love it!  It was easy to assemble.  It is light weight, so it is easy to run.  What took me so long before I bought a Dyson!!!Buford, GA

I have the DC14 and the DC33 is basically an updated version.  The vacuum is phenomenal for cleaning and you really will be amazed at what it removes from your carpet.  They made a few improvements like the extending wand has a button to unlock it on the handle and the attachments lock in with a click.  My only complaint with the DC33 is the attachments they provide now.  The brush head is much smaller than the old brush and it is fixed to the neck attachment.  Rather than being able to remove it is just slide down over the neck piece and it very narrow.  Not a big problem but after using the old brush attachment and the new one I really like the old version better.

column7: Does what it's supposed to do
column8: This thing is amazing! Sure it's a little heavy and a bit clunky, but the suction power is incredible. I did expect the plastic to be more heavy duty (feels a little cheap), but perhaps they did that to keep the vacuum itself lighter. I'm hoping this will last many years. I'm giving it a 4 because of a few things - and because I think that the price could be cheaper.- I LOVE the fact that I can vacuum floors - NO more broom! It gets carpets and floors clean fast and there's no left over stuff on the floors (nice for those of us who have babies/crawlers). I've found that since I've used this weekly, our house has been cleaner (less dusty) overall.- I only use attachments in the bathroom because long hair will get stuck in the roller part underneath.- I wish the canister was washable. When we vacuum the area where our dog sleeps the canister retains that smell for a while, but it sucks up dog hair well.- I have noticed some dust on the outside of the vacuum. Not sure why.- Filters were easy to clean - be sure to clean them as instructed. I did notice loss of suction when they weren't cleaned.- Our carpets do look better and less matted down.- The extender part sometimes doesn't want to stay pulled out.- The long cord is really nice, but I agree that a retractable cord would be extra nice!Overall it's way better than our old vacuum and if we get many years of use of out it, I'll be thrilled.

I bought this because I was fed out w/ the amount of dog hair from my chocolate lab on my white kitchen floor and tan carpet. This got out 90% of it out of the carpet and 100% off the kitchen floor. the wand is a little weird to use at 1st, but once you get use to it, it is ok. The suction is awsome and I think it was well worth the money. Great Product!!!

Really like this vacuum! It is a bit awkward when using the cleaning tools. It's hard to pull the vacuum around b/c the hose is stored in the handle.  I drag it by  the the handle on the bagless cylinder, but it's awkward. The side suction (up against your baseboards) is phenomenal! The ease of emptying the bagless cylinder is wonderful. We're not an allergy family, but spent the extra $ for the HEPA version of the DC33. The filters are washable, no replacing!

Well, i've been using the DC18 'Slim' for 4 years, trouble free, a joy to use, powerful suction, super easy to maneuver, vacuuming was never so easy and fast, easy empty the bin, easy to clean.  i was living in a large two bedroom apartment. I've now moved to a 1600 sq ft house and want to get a bigger Dyson.  I decided, after thinking about the DC25 and DC28 that the DC33 was the best choice for me, taking price into account, and i only need something simple that has great suction and isn't too heavy. I looked at one at a store, found it to be surprisingly lightweight and about as easy to maneuver as the DC18, though much bigger.  So, i ordered one on Amazon and it was delivered a few days ago.I tried it out, it worked great, i had a few frustrations, most of which could be chalked up to being new to it and there being differences compared to what i was used to with the DC18, and also, i was in a rush at the time so i didn't want to take a lot of time with it.One small frustration was that you can't remove the bin if the cord is wrapped up. It took me a while to figure out why i couldn't get the bin off after i had been able to get it off earlier. Another was that there was an exhaust smell when i was vacuuming the second time and my eyes started burning. I called Dyson and they said it was probably just because it was new and that would go away. I've had that same feeling with other appliances so i was ok with giving it some time.One thing that was a disappointment was that i had invested in a lot of accessory tools with the DC18, flat out (type) tool, mini turbine, soft dusting brush and a few others, mattress tool, etc.  They did not fit with the DC33.  I asked Dyson if they had an adapter for that and they said they did and were ready to send it right out to me, so i appreciate that.  However.... i had not registered yet and am not going to, which brings me to the issue which is causing me to return the vacuum cleaner.  I haven't seen this mentioned in reviews so i guess it means i'm probably just a clutz or something, like it must be my fault, or an assembly glitch on the machine, but what happened just now is, I went to clean the beater brush bar for the first time, it's covered in hair.  The DC18 is simple to clean, the bar is in two sections and they slide out either on the left or the right for cleaning. I already knew the DC33 bar doesn't come out, someone mentioned that in a review.  And in the illustration 'instructions' for the vacuum, it showed a picture of someone removing debris with scissors while the bar was still in the vacuum.I cut the hair with scissors and began pulling it out, trying to pull it off the brush.  I found that on the right side (when facing the bottom of the vacuum while it's laying on its back) the brush bar does pull out, which surprised me at first. When i pulled on the hair, the bar came out on the right side, and then it would go back into place.  Then as i continued to tug on the hair to pull it from the bristles, it snapped or popped and changed position, and i found i could not get it back in. Something got out of alignment and the bar would not fit back inside the casing. i tried and eventually got it forced back in but the bar didn't turn easily and it didn't seem right. I turned it on and not surprisingly, it made the really loud noise that it also made when i pushed it over the edge of a rug a couple of times, that other reviewers have mentioned.This was bad.  I called Dyson and described what happened and she said that i would have to send it in for repair. That's not going to happen.  I don't know if this happened because of my error in pulling on the hair too hard but i don't think this would've happened if there had been written directions warning of a need to be cautious when pulling the hair on the right side. I didn't know there was any problem until it was too late.My experience with two calls to customer service was good. The first representative was pretty abrupt but she was ready to submit a warranty claim even though she was implying it was my fault in saying 'YOU pulled the bar out and YOU pulled the clutch and belt out of alignment.'  She really stressed the word 'you.'  But then when i said i would be returning it to the store instead, she tried to trouble shoot it with me, and was clear and methodical in walking me through the steps. Unfortunately it didn't fix the problem.  My second call was about the exhaust smell/burning eyes and the question about an adapter for the accessories. She was quite a bit more pleasant than the other representative and she made it clear that returning the unit to the store and NOT sending it in for repair was the right choice, and she answered questions i had about comparisons between the different models. Along with other useful information, she gave me all the specifications of the DC 25, DC28 and DC33 which i hadn't been able to find so far.OK, so, i did like the vacuum cleaner while using it. It worked fine, was easy to push around and to lift, it was powerful, it was easy to clean, it's simple which i like, the fewer electronic parts the better, fewer things to wear out and go wrong, compared to the DC28, but i may end up going with the DC28 because it's a lot bigger than the DC25.  I'm definitely disappointed in the way the bar popped out on the DC33, i wasn't using any more force than i've used pulling hair off any other vacuum cleaner. I have an iRobot that i had to give up using because of the frequency that it needed hair taken off, it was more work than any other vacuum i've used. I have a cat and a dog, Cavalier King Charles, pretty hairy. For the iRobot, i bought several cutting tools to make it as quick and easy as possible to get the hair off. I used these on the DC33 but there still is some pulling involved.Im giving 3 stars.  Not giving 5 stars because i don't think it was my fault that the bar popped out and it is not a good experience. Not giving less than 3 stars because before this problem happened, it seemed to work well (i would've waited to review it for a month or two) and met my needs and also, i appreciated the customer support experiences.

I was looking to buy this vacuum when, talking to a carpet store owner and installer, I was told that there are some of the more expensive carpets that the guarantee is actually void if you have used a Dyson on them.  Yes, great suction, but too much can actually pull up the carpet fibers.  Be careful if you have new carpeting.
Quite, easy to handle, lightweight and POWERFUL. Handy and useful accessories, No filters to replace. Expensive but worth it. It makes loud noise while working on thick rugs, only drawback.

column7: You don't realize how much dirt your old machine was missing!
column8: The first time we used the Dyson, the dirt container was pretty much full! There was more cat hair and dirt that you could believe hidden in the rugs and carpet! Now with regular vacuuming our carpet looks really great again!

Recently I moved into a new house with wood floors, while I did not want to go through the expense of purchasing a new vacuum, I just settled for using a microfiber sweeper to sweep the floors. First it was a daily chore taking about 30 minutes to dust the entire house, then cleaning the sweeper. What I found out was that my front door has not been properly sealing and letting dust in because every morning my floor in the hall would look like it had not been swept. I then started looking for a new vacuum, my previous vacuum was a Hoover windtunnel, which says it all when it comes to noise. Read hundreds of reviews for vacuums at different sites (some were clearly cut an pasted because they were the same word for word), but I was interested in a Dyson for sometime now. Looked at one of the ball models because of the ease in handling but there was some trade offs on canister size and other things. Finally I decided to purchase the DC33 model. (used my credit card rewards points)and was essentially free. So far I have been happy with this vacuum, as I do not have pets and no carpets, it works very well on my wood floors, if Dyson can come out with a retro fix to solve the tool suction problem, then this would make a good vacuum excellent. Maneuverability on wood floors very easy as it slides around easily. I do have to use a smaller hand held vacuum to vacuum where I would use the tool wand to vacuum, for me that's a large draw back, and for that reason stops me from giving a 5 star rating.Pros: - Much quieter, less noise I can hear my phone ring. - Easy and light to push - Nice long cord, do not have to unplug, can do entire house from a central plug - Nice large container, and easy to empty - Very easy to put together right out of box, less than 10 minutesCons: - Tool suction just sucks, has very little suction, does not even suck up jean pant leg. Leading consumer magazine also noted this - Extension handle a little to big which makes it difficult to reach under master bed, must be turned sideways to slide under bed. - Front of vacuum to high and does not reach base boards under kitchen cabinets

I really read all kinds of reviews of different models before deciding on this mahcine.  First I did a test I have read about, vacummed an area of my rug with my cheapo eureka, then revacummed 1/2 of it again with the eureka and 1/2 with the Dyson.  The eureka picked up more dust etc. than the Dyson,  Hummm.  Vacummed my whole wall to wall carpet, no problems, a little heavier than my eureka, but ok.  Next tried it on a plush 9X12 area rug.  Extremely heavy to push and I can't adjust the vacuum height, like I can on my eureka.  I am returning it for this reason, don't want to break my back trying to push this thing, also it is making that banging noise many others talk about, sounds like it could break any minute.  I have read many reviews that the wand is basically unuseable.  So back to the store, and I'll never buy a high end vacuum again, I've always had good luck with the cheapos.

I just bought this Dyson, it was $320 at Walmart.com.  There are several things going for it.1) Very Easy to put together2) Very Powerful Suction3) Easy to emptyI used my old vacuum (A Bissell) on 3/4 or my apartment when it suddenly died.  I went out and picked this up at Walmart (the manager agreed to match the website price). I took it home, put it together and vacuumed the whole apartment.  It pulled out half a bin of dirt on a carpet that had been steamed or shampooed the week before (I just moved into the apartment).I do have a few complaints.1) I wish the instructions had words and pictures instead of just pictures on how to put it together. It would just make it a little faster.2) The design of the vacuum keeps it from getting under the edge of beds, but I guess that's what the attachments are for.Overall, it is the best vacuum I have ever purchased.

I have read many many reviews on the Dyson DC33 before purchasing. While the majority of them are positive, and I agree, there are a few negative reviews that are just ridiculous.First, I agree that the extension arm does appear cheap and is awkward to use. Does it work, yes. Does this bother me? Not enough to give the vacuum a terrible review. This is the only reason I give it 4 stars. The handle to the wand is a bit flimsy. I get around this by actually holding the wand itself and not the handle.Other than the above, the suction is fantastic. We purchased this vacuum for our new home. The previous owners had pets and vacuumed and shampooed the carpets before we moved it. The DC33 still pulls up dog and cat hair that the previous owners could not get out of the carpet. I have used this vacuum to clean my car and vacuum up dust from sanding our walls. I havent found any other flaws in it, other then the extension wand.As for the other negative reviews. Someone stated that they were disappointed that they had to unravel the cord themselves? Cmon... You cant expect your vacuum to do everything for you. This just screams lazy. Others have commented that it wont reach under the couch. Well, Then move the damn couch. You can effectively vacuum under your couch completely without moving it anyway. There was one other that states that Dyson was liable for damaging hardwood or linoleum floors because their floors weren't level. How is this the fault of the vacuum? Sounds to me like someone didnt install your floors correctly. Last on that list, the attachments are too complicated to use for your maid? Are you kidding? This thing is really easy to use. Why not try reading the instructions.Why did I get a Dyson? Simple reason, my mother. She has had pets all her life and I have never seen a vacuum pull as much hair out of a rug as her Dyson Animal does. I got a good feel for the vacuum at her house while visiting. We decided on the DC33 because we do not have pets and the Animal was overkill for us.For the best pricing out there, go to banksvac.com. We got our DC33 for $309 shipped. Free shipping, No taxes and at least $90 less than anyone else that has this vacuum for sale.Is it perfect, no. But it is still a damn good vacuum in my book and I would buy another one if I needed to.

column7: I wanted one for so long!
column8: The Dyson DC33 Multi floor is perfect for my home (carpet, wood floor, stairs, linoleum).  I have tested other Dyson vacuum models with ball technology, but I definitely prefer the DC33.  It feels much easier to control than the ball.  I don't find it very difficult getting around furniture or tight spots.  If I can't get to something I use the attachments which I like to use anyway for stairs, base board and trim.  If you are on the fence about which model to buy - I recommend going for the DC33.

I read a lot of reviews before buying this vac. I upgraded from a walmart-$80 special that I had for a few years. I finally caved when the on/off button stopped working. So after alot of research I bought my Dyson. So excited I put it together (couple quick pieces, no issues) and vacuumed my low pile area rug. I have never heard a worse screeching grinding noise in my life! I turned it off, checked for jams, pieces etc and tried again. Same issue. I googled the problem and it seems like everyone who has low pile carpets has this issue. Dyson recommends removing a seal from around the beater to reduce the suction. Pardon me, but isnt the reason we all bought this vacuum for its amazing suction? I have not removed the seal and I live with the noise. Other than that, it works great on my hardwood and tile floors (you can actually see the dogs hair getting pulled from under the couches!) and great on normal carpet (although sometimes I dont see the brush marks on the rug which made me not believe it was actually spinning), however the amount of dirt, fur and dust in the canister proves me wrong. Other cons: the attachments are NOT easy to use-its a pain to disassemble the handle, flip it around etc. Pro's-great suction, large capacity dirt bin. Bottom line, worth the price.

After 13 yrs our vacuum decided to start showing it's age.  We had a Eureka.  It kept clogging and losing suction even after we changed the bag.  Time for a new vacuum.  We started at Sears and looked at all of their Dyson models a well as their other models.  They wanted $400-500 for one of their Dysons.  We wanted a bagless that could handle pet hair as we have 4 cats.  To make a long story short, we could not justify paying $400-500 for a vacuum when we found the Hoover Wind Tunnel PAWS at Target for $150.00 (including tax).  It has a retractable cord, one washable filter and one replaceable filter.  It comes with a brush that attaches to the hose for vacuuming your furniture.  It's not any heavier than our old vacuum nor is it any noisier.  When the canister gets full, take it to the trash and empty it out.  It works just as well as any Dyson out there but for less than half the price.  It sucked up A LOT of crap that our old vacuum left behind.  We like it and think that Dyson is over hyped.

Excuse the cliche pun, but this vacuum sucks.  It really is powerful and really gets the carpet clean.  I have two short haired dogs and this gets the job done well.  It doesn't have all the bells and whistles as other dyson models do, but it gets the dirt and dust out just the same.  The vacuum is not very heavy and move around very easily.  The extension hose is a little stiff as others mentioned, but if you stretch it all the way out before you use it, it's not too bad at all.  The is the biggest difference you will see between dyson and other brands, the suction power on the hose.  It really is strong and especially great for vacuuming the crack where the carpet meets the wall.

We've been using the DC33 multi-floor for a few months now, and I tend to agree with the overall content of many of the previous reviews.PROS: The vacuum does have very powerful suction. It is reasonably light and carrying it from one floor to another is not a issue. When used as an upright it is quite maneuverable. It does a very good job on both hard floors (hardwood and tile) and carpet. Emptying the cannister is simple.CONS: The wand attachment is so problematic that is almost useless. The coiled hose does not stay extended and I am constantly fighting it as it tries to retract itself. The vacuum will occasionally tip over as I fight the hose to clean under furniture and on the stairs. I find the hose so disappointing because I really like the vacuum otherwise. I would give it 3.5 stars if Amazon allowed fractions.

This is my second Dyson.  The first (I don't recall the model)was quite the machine.  This one however, reeks of cheapness. I really miss the smoothness and strength of the aluminum wand.  This one feels like it might break apart upon lifting.  It does however, work very well; at least that hasn't changed.As for the weight, I don't mind; the weight is mostly electric motor (my opinion)and  this to me, spells quality.  The heavier the motor the stronger (again my opinion) and should give it a longer life.My first unit developed a problem and I took it in for repair.  The cost was as much as a new lesser vacuum.  I added a few bucks and bought one (they didn't sell Dyson) and went on my way.  The first time I had to change the bag I knew I had made a mistake.  What a pain.  I should have bitten the bullet, paid for the repair and called it good.I considered returning the new one but I'll give it a chance.  I'm sure I'll wind up keeping it.  Even with all the plastic it's still better than all the others I've tested, and I'd recommend it to anyone who wants clean carpets.

This is my second Dyson.  My first was older and filters were impossible to clean and unit croaked.  This new one has easy access filters and cleans like nobody's business.  Love it.  My daughter wants to toss her old one and get a new one just like it.
Does an awesome job picking up pet hair from our carpets and wood floors.  Emptying the cannister is way easier that dealing with bags.  Highly recommend.
Have heard about the Dyson.  Wanted one to use to pick up pet hair.  Although our other sweeper worked, it was not getting all the pet hair up.  This one does!!  Great filtering system.

column7: If you have long hair, PLEASE read before purchase
column8: I have very long hair. Our house is practically all carpet so I was willing to shell out money for a nice vacuum. This vacuum is nice, and the suction is great; however, ALL MY HAIR GETS STUCK ON THE BEATER BAR. This is incredibly annoying, as it is a gross, awkward, and frequent job to remove the hair. I don't know if there is a vacuum out there that does the job better, but if hair is your enemy I'd encourage you to keep looking. Also the wand is not convenient, as many reviewers have said. You'd think engineers could figure stuff like this out! I mean, I can't use the wand without the vacuum tipping over. Did they not try out their own product before selling it? Dumb, IMO.
I liked the DC33. It is easy to use and works well. My children like to clean our home with it

This was a top rated vacuum on consumer reports, which is why I bought it initially. So glad I did. Stair tool is very easy to use and the whole vacuum is very lightweight. It is pretty low maintenance as well with very powerful suction. I love that it can clean both my carpets and my hardwood floors.

column7: And you thought your carpet was clean?
column8: After reading a lot of reviews (mainly the negative ones) I decided to go with my prior experience with a Dyson and purchase this model. I could not be more pleased. Running it over a recently cleaned carpet pulled up an enormous amount of dust/dirt/cat hair - ugh! The tools are well thought out and everything is where it needs to be for ease of use. The one complaint I have heard on several occasions that I might agree with a little, is the spring in the attachment hose is a little firm. It may loosen up with use, but it does not detract from a wonderful product. Our floors are mainly carpeted, with some tile.I would highly recommend it.

Summary:  The Dyson DC33 has proved to be a brilliant vacuum cleaning machine for our large Chicago highrise space which, incidently, comprises at least 4 different and materially varying floor surfaces. Nonetheless, you must learn how to use the Dyson, as we did after chucking J. Edgar (our Hoover that had acquired substantial 'dirt' collected from us and others); the machine has its own design parameters which, if _you_ fail to learn to exploit them, may mean that you will be disappointed due to your own shortcomings in this respect, including in the event you fail to investigate myriad helpful videos and similar online resources that, literally, teach how to operate and maintain the machine to an exceedingly fine degree. (Hint: avail yourselves of the online search engines, even YouTube!)  If you bother to appreciate how to apply the DC33 technical design to almost any home or small office environment, we are convinced you will achieve all plausible home cleaning objectives possible given a non-liquid vacuum cleaning machine intended for home use.  OTOH if you choose not to learn new technology, or want it for an industrial shop, perhaps the purchase a Dyson DC33 is not to be recommended.Us:  Middle-aged; frequent 7-continent travelers, backpackers, runners, divers, bikers, and mountain climbers with plenty o' dirt to contribute; no pets (our building doesn't permit them, not even fish); no kids or other family nearby; no car; we both do all cleaning and alternate with the chores and each works 3,000+ hours per year as professionals; we could hire 'help' but lack the trust and never will go there.  Neither has any connection to Dyson or its employees; candidly, our appliances just must work and remains outta the way when unneeded.Cons: The instructional manual, to be proper, could occupy the volume of a modest novel and Dyson does not provide such as hardcopy or even online. Perhaps not the best product for those to the left of the Gaussian curve.  Large staircases might be better addressed utilizing a second machine designed for the particular environment.  Liquids, especially kitchen or garage, well those spilled depositions are a big no-no.Pros: DC33 is readily disassembled and maintained at home. The rigid wand detaches and you can easily connect endpoint attachments directly to the hose coupling for close-in work.  Powerful suction that sustains despite a large volume of material caught in the debris bin.  A long power cord.  Easy and convenient release of the debris bin.  Maneuverable and light in weight.  We recommend Dyson DC33 to our friends and would buy it again.

As an Engineer I really appreciate the thought that has gone into the design of this product. The usability is phenomenal and the lower maintenance (no bags to replace) really makes this a step up from what I was using before. Excellent performance on the cleaning front as well...highly recommended!

Bought our 1st Dyson vacuum in 2002, after a friend told us it was life changing technology. The 1st time we used it, the canister was filled up. Fast forward to today and the same thing happened - guess we should have replaced the old vacuum a couple years ago. This thing cleans floors!

column7: This vacuum damaged my wood floors
column8: This vacuum is not designed well for wood floors/ linoleum. If your floors are not perfectly level, the plastic piece on the bottom will rub your floors. This vacuum did some damage to my floors and dyson would not do anything about it. They said the vacuum was 'mechanically working' and that I ran over 'grit' to do that damage to my floors. They wouldn't give me my money back. They have the worst customer service. They didn't care that I couldn't use it in my house. They didn't disclose that you need to have level floors - they just said that they could see it rubbing the floors if you have uneven floors.

I own a commercial cleaning company, and I just LOVE my Dysons.  I can't even begin to tell you how many other vacs we had prior to switching our fleet over to Dyson's ~ best business decision we've made!

column7: Great Vacuum with Almost perfect score.
column8: Why did I give it 4 stars - Because nothing is perfect but this is about as good as it gets.The only design flaw I have seen is in where the bag-less container connects to the suction. It may wear out after a while. But with all things like this time will tell. It held together with pressure, its not 100 inserted into the one another.The attachment hose is Long, and you have to pull it out to use it properly. This would have been better if it was shorter, but an easy work around is having the vacuum a few feet away from you and it works great then. This is not a design flaw because if you have 10Ft ceilings you need the length.I clean the floor in 1 carpet room, then switch to hardwoods and do the second room with out having to shut is off.The brushes pick up hair and get wrapped around but that is common with all vacuums, and the quarter release clips are great. No tools to use, and no pieces to lose. Snaps in snaps out and your done cleaning the brushes. The rubber belt is also protected from dirt and other items by this plate. Not common with any other vacuum I have ever used.Hardwood is a breeze, has not left a single mark on mine in the month we have been using it.The first time I used it I had to empty the container every time I was done with a room. Not to say it was dirty, because I used our old vacuum the day before getting this one. But that is how much the other vacuum missed.

This vacuum is all it says it is.  I just moved to a new apartment 2 weeks ago.  We have brand new carpet and we dont wear shoes in the house.  I just bought a new dyson vacuum and it was amazing the dust and debry it picked up even with new carpet and no shoes in house!  In regards to some people saying that using the hose was a little awkward; it says you can use the brush attachements on the hose or the stick part.  If you don't like the long stick just dont use that part.  Anyhoo, I love it! :D

column7: An Amazing Product, definitely worth it
column8: It's a 4 star rating, but that's only because I'm one of those that reserves 5 stars for the most amazing of things.This review will have two parts.  First, just an overall review and second, why I chose this over the DC25 (which is what I was pretty much decided on until I ran across a DC33 on the floor at a local store).This is my first Dyson, and after reading all the reviews it seems like the majority of people love it, and a few hate it and it seemed like mechanical problems were pretty common.  I've only owned for a short time, but I just don't see this vacuum giving me any problems **assuming you take care of it like you would have to any vacuum***. The sucking power is amazing, we vacuum our home once a week and after giving the dyson a quick run over all our floors (carpet, tile and wood); i ended up having to empty the canister 3 times.  On tile and wood, you can see hairs being sucked in from a few feet away.  From carpets it picked up very very fine dust.  Emptying the canister really is extremely easy. Reaching the filters to wash (at least once every 3 months) is incredibly easy and it even has easy ways to check and clean the vacuum for possible clogs.The main negatives of this vacuum is the wand can be a little awkward to use.  I think that's just inherent in any wand tool.  It's definitely not 'useless' as I always use it here and there, just be prepared for the sucking to start as soon as you put the vacuum upright which other reviews have noted.  You can either just be aware that it'll happen, or you can turn off the vacuum before switching to the wand.  (the on/off button is easy to reach so it's not much of a hassle really)The actual vacuum is a little bulky so you can't maneuver underneath low furniture.  It did go underneath my dining table with no problems. and I don't really have any other furniture that i need to go under.those are really the only two cons i see for this.  some people complain that it's made of 'cheap plastic'.  It's made of polycarbonate plastic.  Known for being incredibly durable yet being extremely light.  And the vacuum is indeed pretty light for the size. It glides just as easy as any other vacuum i've used.Now, why did I choose this over the DC25? Wife tried pushing both around the store and didn't find the DC25 any easier to maneuverer.  Some people do, so just give it a try. But honestly even if the DC25 does move easier, it's a $100 more.  Second, the DC33 has more sucking power.  It's a vacuum. It needs to suck, more sucking power = better in my book.  Third, it has a much larger canister.  I think twice the size if i remember the numbers correctly off of dyson's website.  Fourth,  it's electric cord is 10ft longer.  I can vacuum my whole master bedroom and bathroom without unplugging the thing once.  These 4 reasons just made it a much more practical buy than the D25 in my book so that's why I went with this model instead.Either way, after being hesitant for a few months by some of the bad reviews Dyson gets, i am throughly satisfied.  The wand isn't as easy as I wish, but wand use for me is very secondary and it still has its use.  It almost seems like the air in my house is cleaner after getting rid of all the dust embedded in my carpets / rugs.  The design of how to clean the canister, filters and vacuum itself makes usually very tough tasks, quite simple.

column7: Originally Four stars, now One-hose failed
column8: The hose came apart this morning. I bought the Dyson in Feb 2011. It is less that 2 years old & was lightly used. A replacement hose is $50.Not happy. Fortunately there is Duct Tape, but if I wanted a trashy-looking vacuum I would not have paid for a Dyson.I think because of the Dyson 'hype' many people - including myself - expect the ultimate machine.cons:* I had a cheap Hoover bagless that died after 3 years. The canister would always have a layer of fine particles - but the Dyson seems to pick up less fine particles. The Hoover canister would be full after a vacuuming, the Dyson only  has a couple of inches of fur, etc. Maybe it compresses the dirt more? *The Dyson vents out the front under the canister and blows dust away from the machine - sending dust bunnies scooting.[In the NYT today there was an article on dust. It said that much of the dust on furniture comes from disturbing the dust on the floor while cleaning].* Using the machine is not intuitive - unlike others I've had that came out of the box and you knew just what to do...I had to read the instructions to figure out how it worked. The air blowing out the top of the handle had me stumped at first. I thought there was a piece missing.* Using the wand is not intuitive - it is awkward and takes some getting used to.* Pricey - I paid 319 at Lowes - a good deal, but still pricey.I am hoping that it lasts a long time - that will make it cost effective.pros:*The machine appears to be well built and it looks good.* After using the Dyson a few more times I am liking it better. It is getting easier to use now that I understand it better, but I still dread having to use the wand because it takes some doing to unsnap & get it snapped back onto the machine.* It's a good cleaner, gets the job done.* It picks up kitty litter very well. All my other machines made the litter kick out under the machine. The Dyson picked up every crumb cleanly

I did a lot of research before I bought this Dyson and almost got the DC28 Animal one because I have a large dog that sheds.  After doing some reading online, I found out this is the exact same machine as the animal except for the attachments!  That's the only difference!  So I decided for $200 less than the Animal one I could do without the 'special' attachments.  The very first time I pulled this out of the box and used it in my living room I wasn't all that impressed, especially with the suction but I decided to go over my floor again and practice with the attachments.  Well, it must have just needed to warm up or something being brand new because the second time the suction was amazing!!  (and ever since!)  It left the lines on the carpet from where I had vacuumed (I love that!) and it also fluffed up the carpet and made it feel like when we first bought the carpet and our feet sank down in it a bit!! Very cool!!  And the best part - it picked up the dog hair!!!!!  With my old vacuum I would still get dog hair on my clothes even after vacuuming but I tested my Dyson:  After vacuuming with it the first day I had my toddler drag a clean black shirt all over the carpet - and guess what? - not a single dog hair was on it!! Every time I've used it since the suction has been amazing!Below I wanted to address some of the negatives I have read in reviews about it.  I was glad I ignored them and bought this anyway!  :)- I was impressed with the suction from the side of it.  With the front you can't get right up to the baseboards but if you can run the side of the vacuum against it, it works good (or just use the wand).  On another note about the front - no it won't get under furniture or the edge of things.  The high profile of the front of the vacuum prevents that but that was ok with me.  With this kind of strong suction I wouldn't want to be vacuuming where I can't see what it might grab anyway!  And you can tell by looking at the picture that it won't do this before you buy.. not sure why some people are surprised by this.- THE WAND: this did take some practice but I like it fine.  Some have said the vacuum tips over when you are trying to use it but I haven't had that happen at all.  In fact, when I've been using the wand on the baseboards and walk and pull, the vacuum has actually rolled along behind me like a canister vacuum would do following me!  Just make sure the back of the vacuum where the wand was is facing you so it can roll along with you while you walk.  I also read several reviews saying the wand will suck your shirt sleeve in (because the wand is the handle and the suction switches to the wand when the vacuum is in the upright position.)  But I have a very simple fix for this - TURN THE VACUUM OFF BEFORE putting it to the upright position. Not sure why you would need or want it on while getting the wand or attachments out and ready anyway.  Just turn it off before switching. (and the same when starting to vacuum - recline it first, THEN turn it on.)  One more thing on the wand - I will say that it would be easier if the long end piece was flexible or if the hard section wasn't so long.  It is a bit awkward at first figuring out the best way to use it. I found that if you just back up a bit from what you are trying to vacuum it gives room for you to manuever the long wand.  Just don't get so close and it's no big deal. I will say it IS nice though to have a long hard section wand to get cobwebs on high cielings.- Unlike what some have said, this vacuum is NOT heavy!  They must have been comparing it with a swiffer mop or something because as far as regular vacuums go I was very happy with the weight!  (go to a store and pick them up to compare.)  It's actually much lighter than most I tried out in the stores.  It is easy to push even on my thick carpet!  It's not bulky either and I find it very manuevarable.  In fact I tried out the 'ball' dyson in the store and didn't think it was any more manueverable than the regular one. I also didn't like the release on the ball one (that reclines it to vacuum than clicks it to upright.)  I had to use such force to push on the foot lever to get it to recline that I could see it breaking after awhile.  Not sure if that was just an issue with the floor model or what but I'm very glad I didn't get the ball type.  (the canister is smaller on those too!)- THE CANISTER: is VERY easy to dump.  My old bagless vacuum you had to take the top off the canister and actually dig out the junk.  This one has a very handy release on it:  You take the canister off the vacuum (with one hand at the click of a button!), and while holding it down in the trash can, you push the button that opens the BOTTOM of the canister letting all the junk fall out the bottom down into the trash.  Now you do have to use your fingers to then close the bottom up, but come on - two fingers with a little dust is much better than most!  And it's easy enough to just wash my hands afterwards.- NOISE LEVEL:  It's pretty quiet as far as vacuums go.  My young kids used to be afraid of my vacuum and would run for cover every time I got it out.  The first time I used this one they not only came out in shock that it wasn't some monster going to eat them but they actually skipped across in front of it playing while I vacuumed!- BARE FLOOR TO CARPET LEVER:  Some have said this is a hard thing to do... that confuses me because it is just a wheel like switch on the front of the vacuum that you just turn to 'bare floor' or 'carpet'.  Ok, so you do have to bend down... is that a problem? .. I don't think so.  (sorry for the sarcasm. lol)OK, so after all the good now I will share the short bad.  The ONLY problem I have had with this at all:It tends to leave a clump of dog hair at the last place it was standing when I'm done and turn it off.  I realized though this was probably because I was turning it off so fast when I was done that the last thing it picked up hadn't made it up into the canister yet.  I solved this problem by letting it run for a few seconds in the same position when I was done before turning it off.  That lets all the last stuff it picks up get up into the canister so when I turn it off there's no clump left.  It was a simple fix I just remember to do each time when I'm finished.  I'm happy to do that little thing for the benefit of all that dog hair being gone!  :)So overall I am VERY pleased with this vacuum and highly recommend it - especially if you have pets.

Outstanding machine.  I'm an engineer, so I'm really picky with mechanical devices that they a) function as promised and b) have durable construction so I don't have to constantly maintain them.  This lives up to it.  It's a simple, durable construction and really has the power to clean floors.  Well worth the money.

Just my two bits... Do not waste money on a Dyson! What a disappointment!Suction is poor and it will not go underneath furniture unless it a 1 foot off the floor. After spending $400 on a vac we need to spend more money to buy an attachment to reach under furniture that an $80 el cheap-o-lah vacuum will easily reach under? Oh and you know that little 3 inch area under your countertops in the kitchen? Well, forget cleaning it with the Dyson. It doesn't even leave a nice neat brush stroke on the carpet so you know your carpet is clean.Did I mention the poor suction, on another note if you have long hair expect to clean the brush bar every other time you use this hunk of junk. This junker is NOT light weight and is like pushing a dead freaking fish along the carpet. I want back my $80, self propelled, hepafilter, bagless, lightweight cheap-o-lah that sucked air like a jet engine!And this brings me to the telescoping wand.  For starters, the quick release is in an awkward position.  This means you are more than likely going to turn the vacuum off when trying to release the wand.  Once it does release, you will find that the handle is positioned in a way to make it very uncomfortable to use.What I'm really pissed about is that for $320 more than the little champ I used to have, I expected the Dyson to suck the paint off a 57 Chevy, not suck you know what.  If I could give it a negative 5 star rating, I would!The really sad thing is that we took the first Dyson back because it didn't suck at all and really expected an improvement over the one with broken brush bar.  What a waste of money!

column7: Research for best Dyson--daughter's Christmas wish list
column8: My daughter requested a Dyson vacuum for Christmas so I did online research on Dyson vacuums.  The last research effort was one hour and 1/2 on the internet and phone with my girl friend discussing the various models, features and prices.  I found this model to be the best price and best one for my daughter and that's when I ordered it from Amazon.com.  Free shipping and it came within 2 days...and that was the week before Christmas. My daughter's comment recently was that it worked well.

column7: I wanted to love this machine
column8: Let me start by saying that I really wanted to love this vacuum when I bought it!  For the $399.00 retail it should have been fabulous!  Unfortunately it didn't measure up to its price.Pros: It was lighter than my old Hoover Wind tunnel vac which made it easy to get up and down the stairs, and I really loved the long chord!  I liked the fact that the filters are washable and don't need to be replaced. The suction at the front edge of this vacuum was great.  Unfortunately that was the only place that it pulled dirt up well.Cons: As I stated the frontal suction was great, however the side edging was horrible!  I tried to suck up tinsel next to the upstairs railing in my home after Christmas. No matter how many times I went past the stuff it just would not lift from the side edge.  When I turned and ran the vac over the tinsel from the front it finally came up.  This happened in a few spots.  Needless to say that if you were in tight quarters and couldn't turn the vacuum you would have to use the hand held wand.  On that note, let me say that this vac does have a long hose...if you can get it to stay extended.  The hard plastic nozzle at the end is great if you are sucking cobwebs off of the ceilings but you can't bend the thing around for closer items.  And as I said, the hose (while it was new at least) didn't want to stay stretched out. So unfortunately this feature was basically useless for me.  This vacuum vents the air at the front so when you go to use it on hard wood floors or tile the dust bunnies all float away from you and you end up trying to run them down before they get away.  It might be an amusing diversion if you had the time...! If you are a dust allergy sufferer I would steer clear of any of the bagless vacuums that I've seen, including this one.  Removing the dust from the bin can get you covered in the stuff (Even if you put it in a bag and then open the bottom trap door). The dust gets trapped somewhat inside the canister and then you have to tap and bang on the cheap feeling plastic to get it all out.  By that time you are covered in dust! I would wonder how long the plastic would hold up to the dust removal process as well.Overall it was a so-so vacuum.  But with a large dog and kids running through the house it wasn't any bargain for me!  The price was too much for its usefulness.

Love the Dyson 33. The first time I used it I was amazed what it picked up. I swept with my old sweeper right before and the dyson picked up alot more. The only thing I would say could be better is the wand. When you try to use it the sweeper doesnt hold still and either falls over or rolls behind you.
Product was well packaged. Easy, simple to read instructions. Low maintenance product. Vacuum suction power is incredible. Love all the attachments. All in one product.

column7: Vacuums well; cleaning wand awkward to use
column8: I bought a Dyson DC33 after a friend recommended Dyson products.  The Dyson DC33 cleans very well.  I re-vacuumed the floors 2-3 days after vacuuming with the previous vacuum I owned.  Visibly, there was a lot of dirt in the canister that the previous vacuum did not pick up.The machine is well designed and constructed and easy to use.  Taking apart the canister and wand attachment is very intuitive.  The only things I don't like about the machine is the weight of the machine and the springiness of the wand tube, which makes it difficult to use, as it is always pulling the wand back.

column7: good product if you know it's limits
column8: bought mine 2 months ago at Home Depot!  It was a super special in the store, never saw it for that price before or after.The vacuum provides great suction. More the power of a shop vac for the rug. Picked up things you wish it didn't, dust, dirt, sand! I live in the NE - inland.  So for that part it is great.  I knew it wouldn't fit under furniture - duh!  For those who complaining about it, you  saw it before you bought it.  The wand works very well in lieu of getting under, just remember un crimp it before you use it and the hose is flexible.  What seems like a good thing is a little annoying is the empty canister activity.  All the junk you pulled up just flies from the end of the canister.  You have to hold it deep enough in the garbage or a bag and then toss it.  I have a lot more dust around the garbage after I empty it. It's okay though.The beater slips sometimes and I have to look at it.  Overall the quality is okay, not great. The constant clipping and un clipping of things with plastic are bound to get loose and break., but for the right price it is worth it.  I tell people to get one if they need a vacuum.  I actually like this better then the ball one; the head was too floppy when I tried to lift the whole thing to do the steps. So again this one after much research has done well so far for me.

column7: Great cleaning power in a reasonably sized vac
column8: In our old home I had a Dyson DC21 canister vac that I loved - it was very powerful and easy to each in all the nooks and crannies, it was a small house with hardwood floors and awkward spaces to vacuum. However when we moved to out new condo, which has about 650 square feet of medium pile carpet in the huge bedroom and 3 levels (2 flights of stairs) and I found the canister much less convenient for this arrangement. SO I decided to sell the DC21 and buy a cheaper upright vac. I got the Hoover T series bagged ('HEPA' bag - I put that in quotes because it's not a true HEPA system) Windtunnel but I was very unhappy with it - poor suction which I was not able to fix, the door of the bag compartment wouldn't close tightly which may have contributed to poor suction, and the plastic parts were very cheaply made. I very much missed my Dyson and was unhappy that I'd sold it for the inferior Hoover. I returned the Hoover and went shopping for a Dyson upright, resigned to spending more money than I'd been able to sell my used Dyson for.I tried out the Ball models and I liked the agility and flat front that would fit under cabinets, but the DC24 in my price range had a very small dirt bin, and less suction than the DC33 and a more fiddly wand assembly. The DC25 is great but a lot more expensive. I decided to go with the DC33 and I like it - light enough to carry up stairs, but very powerful cleaning. I plan to buy a mini turbine head to clean under furniture with the wand attachment. The dirt bin is easy to empty into a bag without puffing dirt all over, important for allergy suffers. And the air exhaust is clean smelling and doesn't trigger my allergies as I vacuum. And like all Dysons, it has major cleaning power!

The positive reviews on this website encouraged to buy this thing.  I would like to save you my grief. The only good thing on this vacuum is the suction -- but other vacuums with 12A power have the comparable suction.For a company that claims to solve the design flaws in uprights, they created all new ones.  Most people cited the issue with the wand/hose and attachments but said it didn't bother them -- it wouldn't be a big deal if you could actually reach a couple of inches under the sofa or table, but given the dimensions of the vacuum you can't - and if the wand is hard to use, it makes the entire vacuum hard to use.Point by point, here is why you should NOT buy1) complex to use, my house cleaner was totally confused as I explained to her how to use the wand, the attachments, and how to reinstall the cup2) the hose wand is very difficult and cumbersome to use -- the wand is too long and the unwieldy3) the attachments are worthless and you can't use them to properly clean stairs4) it's bulky, far bulkier than the Eureka and Hoovers I've used5) because the wand is not functional, you can't get under any furniture6) all the pieces click into place -but are flimsy -- lots of opportunity for breakage if you force it a little too much or don't align it perfectly7) the vacuum falls over when you you try to use the wand8) when you put the vac in upright position the suction comes from the top of the wand immediately so it you have to quickly shut it off, it grabs my sleeves 9) there are no multiple carpet pile levers10) the location of the bare floor vs. carpet is very cumbersome to use11) the unit is heavier than my other two uprights that had similar power and better functions12) the height on the head of the vacuum is too big so you can't even get a few inches under the sofa13) no retractable cord (not really a big deal -- but for the price -- I'm throwing it in as a con14) the handle is not ergonomically designed well.  I'm short and I feel like I had to bend over as I moved the vacuum forward.I bought on BF for 30% off - it was still $300 -- not worth it.  My $150 vacuum lasted 13 years, was as good at picking up stuff from my plush carpet and oriental rugs, and had a functional wand and functional attachments.this thing is POS. seriously.  save your cash.  It's going back tomorrow.

column7: Superb on floors, but the dust wand is a bit inconvenient
column8: This is a great sweeper, and it really excells at cleaning floors.  The 2010 holiday cyber week saw a handful of retailers discounting the DC33 heavily, which made the deal hard to ignore, especially since the motor bearings on my 25 year old Eureka canister vac were shot.The construction of the DC33 is mostly of well fitting high quality plastic parts that look like they should hold up well to a number of years of use.  The ergomics of the machine are pretty good, especially for floor cleaning.  When the DC33 is parked upright, vacuum is vented through the handle, which doubles as the dusting wand.  Some users reported that was off-putting, but it doesn't bother me.  That keeps a good air flow to the high speed motor and prevents burning out the motor with over speed from too much suction.  And, yes the TV ads seem to be correct in that the DC33 has a lot of suction power.  I've previously had serveral upright sweepers, and they're quite wimpy compared to the DC33.  While the others relied mainly on the brush roll to kick up dirt, which was lazily scooped into a bag, the DC33 really pulls the dirt.  The fist time I went over my carpet with the Dyson, I was surprised at the amount of crud it pulled out.  The really long 35 foot power cord is a nice touch too.  I can reach most of my house without having to re-plug the cord.  The motor isn't silent, but it is quiet enough that it doesn't send my cats running when I switch the DC33 on.The DC33 is bagless, but not totally maintenance free.  There are pre and post filters that need to be periodically washed.  I've used the DC33 several times, and the filters still pretty much look pristine despite having dumped dust collector quite a few times.  The manual is a bit dodgy on how often the filters should be washed, but does give a good illustration of the procedure for doing so.While I am cheery about the quality and power of the DC33, it isn't all peaches and cream.  There are a few week spots.  The bulk of the design makes it hard to sweep under beds or low furniture.  It is better to move things like coffee tables and beds if you need to clean far underneath the edge.  The wand's combo brush/crevice tool isn't much help in the cleaning underneath department becuase the brush is pretty dinky; you'll spend a lot of time with such a small brush.  That's where a canister vac will do better.  If cleaning under things frequently is a must for you, then you might want to consider one of the higher end Kenmore canister vacs as an alternative.  The other mote in the DC33's eye is the somewhat clutzy design of the wand.  While the wand is a bit more convient to stow than the likes of Hoover attachment tools, the problem stems from the rather long wnad stowing inside the hose.  When the wand is extended, it sticks way out from the end of the hose, and it is hard to get a good angle for dusting bick-a-brack on dresser tops and waist level flat surfaces.  On the other hand, the wand is really great for reaching up and nabbing cob webs from high ceiling corners.Over all, the DC33 is a good bargain when it is discounted.  It would be hard to find a better machine for carpet cleaning.  I'd have to think twice, however, at the list price of $399 --  I would have to give consideration to the very capable Sears Kenmore canister vacs at that price point becuase they're be handier for cleaning under beds and doing stairs.EDIT 14-February-2011I figured out that it is possible to detach the wand and sick the crevice tool or upholstery tool directly into the end of the hose.  I'm not sure that it is what Dyson intended; the manual doesn't say anything about attaching the tools that way, but it is unbelieveably easier than trying to use the tools on the end of the wand (except for stairs and ceiling corners).Since figuring this out I will up my rating of the DC33 to 4.5 stars.  The DC33 still loses half a star becuase it is too bulky to sweep easily under low furniture such as beds and coffee tables.

I read the 1 and 2 star reviews before we purchased. We are very pleased with this vacuum so far.The good:The suction is great, and emptying the canister is a breeze. The cord is long (35') and it weighs less than it looks. I ran my old unit, then this, and it picked up more (stuff). It glides across the floor easily even with the 2 wheels. You can easily switch from the roller to non roller for non carpet floors.The bad:I will have to agree that for the cost, some of the plastic parts seem flimsy. Nothing that feels like it is going to snap off, but flimsy feeling none the less. The only weird thing is the auto top suction switch. This is a minor annoyance, but the only real complaint here. I will try to explain:The wand feature works in reverse. The suction comes out the top instead of the bottom of the wand. The wand is essentially the handle and when the vacuum is upright, the wand starts the suction. This is right where your hand, sleeve, watch, bracelet, was a second ago. As soon as you click the vacuum in the upright position, it switches from bottom suction to wand suction. Not a big deal, but if you have on a long sleeve shirt, it can catch you off guard.Summary: A great vacuum. I hope it provides years of dirt pickup and we may buy another.

Overall Dyson DC33 is a good product.The good: strong cyclone effect,  clean medium pile carpet very good. Work flawlessly with carpet, laminate wood floor, tile floors in bathroom. Work best when vacuum wood and tile floors. For kitchen, as long there's 4-1/4' clearance from top of floor to bottom of cabinet, DC33 will clean everything.  Test with small size cheerios, pick them up with no problem. Long electrical cord, bigger trash bin than DC25, clean air exhaust.  Light weight.The bad: stiff hose, hard to use wand.

I have tried both of these, and have come to the conclusion that the DC33 is superior. Here's why:-The suction and brush bar are clearly more powerful. This is what sold me. I can see the difference in carpet lines (medium pile carpet) when I use one or the other.-35ft cord is a significant benefit over the 25ft cord. I can almost do the entire floor by just plugging in a single outlet. Two would cover the whole house. With the DC25, I had to constantly unplug and replug.-Larger dustbin means I can keep vacuuming for longer without emptying. Also, the design on this one seems to keep the shroud (the perforated shield inside the canister) freer of stuck-on dust.-Quieter-Although a bit larger, it is a similar weight to the DC25.-Critical sections can be easily taken apart to clear blockages.-The DC25 has a tiny plastic piece that keeps the vacuum from tipping over in upright mode due to the ball mechanism. If I tilt the vacuum to the side while it is close to being upright, I can hear a loud snap as the plastic piece is forced into a position where it shouldn't be. I can see this breaking really soon.There are some shortcomings:-The wand is a clear cost cutting measure. It is plastic rather than aluminum. Also, the handle is missing (present in the DC25) a contoured plastic piece that makes it much more ergonomic to hold when using the wand. It also requires an extra button to release AND another button to retract the wand. Lastly, when you release the wand from the hose, there is just a bare hose, rather than a similar cuff as the one at the end of the wand with a release button as on the DC25. It is still usable, but not as nice. It just adds to the already cumbersome wand system on the Dysons.-The DC33 switches suction to the wand when in upright position whereas the DC25 switches it when the wand is drawn. A minor annoyance, especially if you're wearing a long sleeved shirt; it may  get sucked in when you hold the handle.-No ball, but to me the difference in maneuverability is negligible.Update 3/4/2011: I have used this vacuum for a few months now. I returned the DC25 and do not miss it at all. The DC33 continues to perform admirably. True to Dyson's claim, the suction is as good as new. I've washed the filters once and the process was simple, much simpler than going to the store and buying filter bags. Vacuuming is a pleasure, due to getting the instant gratification of seeing the the dust collect in the bin, and the clean exhaust. It's probably subconscious, but as a sufferer of seasonal allergies and constant nasal congestion, I feel like I can breathe better when I vacuum.The only pain has been removing hair from the brush bar. It doesn't pop off, unlike the DC25, so removing hair can be a cumbersome process.

column7: Can't reach under my kitchen cabinets!
column8: We bought the Dyson DC33 & had high hopes.  I disliked it from the beginning.  It doesn't feel sturdy, or well made.  I had to go over small strings multiple times to get them up from the carpet, I would think that should be an easy pick up!  I didn't like the way you had to fiddle with two buttons to pull out the long hose from the top & it was very awkward to use.  The vacuum kept tipping over when I'd use it & then it would shut off without me knowing it because it the hose only sucks in a certain position.  I also found that when in 'idle' position...the top of the vacuum sucks your sleeve in if you go near it because that is where the hose part comes from (hard to explain).  Its fine as long as you are in 'vacuuming position' because then the top suction part shuts off.But, the worst part for me was that this vacuum wouldn't reach under my kitchen cupboards to the baseboard.  You have to take out the hose & use it on the edges of the floor because the front of the vacuum is so high that it stops before getting under the cupboards all the way.  I don't think we have deeper than normal cupboards, so can you imagine not being able to just vacuum the kitchen floor without struggling with that awkward hose to do the entire perimeter of the kitchen?!?Anyway, back it went & I'm going with Hoover.  Should have listened to the sales girl!!!

I've been using this product for a month now, and am satisfied overall.  Its suction is incredible, the beater-bar does a great job on big carpets.  Emptying the canister is genius simple - just hold it over the garbage can, press the button, and you are done!  It is relatively lightweight for an upright, and the way it all clips together it is very easy to carry around and up/down stairs.  It also looks cool for a vacuum, so my kids want to play with it (for now, anyway).  Way less hassle than my old FilterQueen with four seperate pieces to lug around!Here's what I would have liked to have known in advance:  The super suction means it tries to eat small throw carpets, and you have to ackwardly put a foot on both ends of the carpet to keep it down while you vacuum it; Although it does have a very long reach when the wand is removed from the upright, the flexible tube is so springy it pulls back on itself and drags the upright part around while you are trying to use the wand part.  It says it reaches 17ft - but effectively it is only usable for about 6-8 feet because of the springiness.  It is really only a FLOOR vacuum, as it cannot be used for things like vacuuming the car, or dusting around stuff on top of the piano or mantle, as the business end of the wand is a four foot straight tube - the flexibility is all at the motor end of the wand.  It does not go under any furniture, but I can live with that.

column7: Great suction.  Heavy and does not reach under furniture.
column8: My new Dyson DC33 arrived today.  Though it has some strongly positive features, overall I am disappointed.PRO's:- Great suction- Pretty quiet- Big canister for vacuumed-up stuff;  easy to empty the canister- The filters will be very easy to rinse- 5-year warranty- Easy to carry around with a well-positioned handleCON's:- Worst thing is that it does not fit under dressers, beds, benches, coffee tables, sofas, etc;  basically can't vacuum under most furniture- Next complaint is that it is awkward to turn the carpet brush on/off;  there is an awkward lever at toe level that is hard to move with my foot- It's heavy and takes muscle to push/pull it on oriental carpets- The telescoping wand tends to pull the vacuum over;  perhaps that will stop in the future, once the hose is less stiffLuckily, I have a small floor vacuum that will go under furniture.  But for $399 I wish I didn't have to use both.UPDATE (same day):  Dyson will allow me to exchange it (I bought it on the Dyson website rather than Amazon).  I am going with the DC23.

You get what you pay for. You want junk? Buy an inexpensive vaccuum cleaner. You want quality that will last for years to come? Buy a dyson. We are filling up our landfills when we buy a vaccuum cleaner once a year like I used to do. Buying a dyson will make the landfills smaller and great for our planet. Less people throwing away their vaccuum cleaners every year. I owned a dyson dc14 model. I never had any problems and it never lost suction. I could see the hair and dust from my hardwood floors attract to my vaccum like a magnet. The hair and dust would be 12 inches away and the stuff just flew accross the floor and right into the vaccuum. We have 2 large dogs and 4 cats and this vaccuum gets all the hair up. I even vaccuum my dog with it. lol. He likes it. I had the dc14 model for a year before I had to replace it cause the dog chewed the cord. This dc33 model is just like the dc14. Looks the same and everything. The only thing I miss from my dc14 is the metal hose. The dc33 has a plastic hose. I would assume that it makes no difference. Maybe the metal hose would last longer? Other than that I love the dc33 model just as much as the dc14 model. The dc33 model works exactly the same as the dc14 model and I have seen no problems. Great suction and everything. I will be a returning customer for life.

column7: Wish I could give it more stars!
column8: This vacuum is AMAZING! My husband and I had a Eureka Maxima, and it clogged all the time, lost suction (from the clogging), and the hose kept falling out. You can only blow a vacuum out so many times with an air compressor before you get sick of it. So, one night, we went shopping for a vacuum. We've wanted a Dyson for so long, and we pushed different models around the store for hours. We finally decided on this one.Pros:-Big canister makes it easy to vacuum for awhile without having to dump (this canister is also bigger than the Ball models).-15 foot cord!!-Quiet. Yes, this vacuum is quiet.-Unmatched suction-Picks up cat hair, dust, dander, dirt, and everything else without a hitch. You only have to go over a spot one time!-Very, very long hose and attachments-Easy to empty canisterCons:-Once you buy this vacuum, you will find it hard to stop using it!Yes, this vacuum is pricey. But it is definitely worth the price. We have 4 long-haired, shedding, exploding cats. They have sterlite tubs as litter boxes and get litter everywhere. It gets into the carpet (we live in an apartment), behind baseboards, just everywhere. Our old vacuum picked up the surface litter but we just couldn't get the embedded litter out no matter how hard we tried. Our house smelled like cat, even after scooping twice a day. We had no idea that a vacuum could take care of such a problem. We come home now and don't smell cat, or cat litter. The carpet looks newer. The couch looks great!This vacuum is worth it, I doubt you will be disappointed!

My husband and I were skeptical about purchasing an expensive vacuum cleaner, especially since we had a bad experience with the Oreck, another expensive sweeper. We then went to Wal-Mart and bought an inexpensive vacuum cleaner which had high reatings on many reviews. Terrible vacuum! It spit dust everywhere. Both my husband and I are very allergic to dust.To make a long story short, we took the plunge and bought the Dyson. As soon as we got it, we swept all the carpets and wood floors in our home.  What a difference! The carpet looked so much cleaner, but, just as important, the air was even cleaner. It was much easier to breath! I was amazed!In all fairness I'm rating it a 4 instead of a 5 since we just purchased the Dyson recently and the jury is still out on the long term effects. We are quite happy with it so far!
I was happy with my product and with how fast it was shipped to me. The vacuum was in the shape it was said to be.
Very impressed!  I could not believe how much this vacuum picked up.  And it makes the carpet look fluffy when I'm done.  I love it!

Excellent suction. Easy to assemble/easy to use/easy to use attachments/easy to remove filters.  Everything clicks in and out of place.  Works real well on pet hair.  If I had a complaint, it would be the attachment hose is a long plastic piece that can't be adjusted and it can be a little awkward in some tighter places.

First Dyson I have owned and really impressed by it. Like the old saying goes, you get what you pay for. I vacuumed my place with an older Eureka before the Dyson arrived to see if it would pick up stuff the old vacuum missed and was amazed at how much the Dyson picked up. Also noticed that I didn't smell any dust leaking from the Dyson as I used it like I did with the older vacuum. Wish I'd bought a Dyson sooner.

column7: Like the machine - hate the attachments
column8: We love the machine.  Bought it to replace our old Dyson which we simply wore out - and loved.  The only thing we really dont like is that the attachment from our old Dyson do not fit our new Dyson - and there are no adapters - and the attachments for this new Dyson really suck.  I'm VERY disappointed that I will now have to go out and buy a bunch of new adapters that don't work nearly as well as the old ones.  Boo!

I was very excited about purchasing a really good vac. Now it is the worse purchase I have ever made in my life. I only have hardwood floors and it has ruined them. So much about being impressed with the 5 year warranty. What good is it since they do not do anything to resolve your problems. They want you to sweep your floors before you vac them. I now have a 4 month old $600 machine that I have no use for. Walmart and Dyson neither one will take it back and refund my money.Be careful and do not make the same mistake I did.
