I saw someone's review here that said it gets stuck on dirty sometimes. I hate to break it to them, but it's probably just their carpet! Ok, ok, that's not very nice. Maybe they've got a clog - the one time it happened to me that was the problem. The indicator light has also turned out to be handy for when the kids vacuum the floor. So far it's been really easy to maintain. No problems there at all. Even when the kids try to pick up something too big it's pretty simple to find and get to the source of the problem... I've never even had to ask my husband for help ;) And because it has such great suction it's obvious when there's an obstruction. Then it's right back to full power!The down sides: Well, not so much down sides as things that would be kinda nice: The stretchy wand tube thingy (that's a technical term) could be a little longer. It reaches everywhere I want to go, but I don't have unusually high ceilings or anything like that. I'd also love it to come with a pet hair roller, but that can be purchaced for pretty cheap. Last thing: how great would it be if it had an automatic cord winder, huh? But perhaps that much perfection in a vacuum cleaner is not meant for this world...Bottom line: An awesome vacuum! Very, very happy with it!

We purchased this vacuum a little over a year ago.The suction on this vacuum is AMAZING! We have an indoor cat in addition to living near the country (a lot of pet hair and dirt).  The first time we used this vacuum we were shocked to see how much dirt was in our carpet (really disgusting).  The embedded dirt finder is really handy too since it tells you if a certain area of carpet needs extra cleaning.  The suction on the attachments is ok, not the best, but we really use it for cleaning the carpets, in which it is excellent!About a month ago, we noticed the vacuum started to make a high pitched noise.  When we took it in, we were told the motor went out!  To our surprise, the vacuum repair place told us that we needed to clean the filters every time!  We followed the manual which states to clean the filters every 2 months.  From this point forward, we are making sure that we clean out the filters after every use (despite the manual stating this should be done every 2 months).  This is kind of annoying to do but overall this vacuum is awesome at cleaning carpets.  Also, I agree with some of the other reviews which state that emptying the canister is messy!  Sliding the clip back in place is sometimes difficult and you do end up getting your hands dirty and full of dust...Beware though in that you need to clean the filters after every use or you can risk serious damage to the machine!  Although this vacuum is great at cleaning, we wouldn't buy it again...

I am just blown away by this vaccum. I had a dirt devil that lasted just over a year. It finally broke down last week. I also had to purchase a new filter for it every 3 months because I have 2 dogs that shed like crazy and 2 cats that also shed. I did some research and talked to my mom debating about what kind of vaccum I should purchase. I wanted to get a vaccum that would last and do a good job. I was debating between a dyson and this hoover. My mom went from an electrolux to a hoover wind tunnel and loves her wind tunnel. She had also used my brother's dyson before and was not impressed. She thought I should just get a regular wind tunnel, but I wasn't sure how well it would pick up the dog hair. I read the reviews about this picking up the dog hair so I decided to go with this one plus it had the wind tunnel technology. I have only had this new Hoover for less than a week but it's already amazing. I used to vacuum every 3 days and I thought my carpet was pretty clean. I've been using the Hoover every day since I got it, and the sensor still says dirty, I wouldn't say the sensor is defective because it's still pulling up lots of hair and dust. My carpet used to be a normal tan color and now it's turning almost white. It also looks extremely fluffy compared to how it used to look matted. I also took it to my mom's house, to see what she thought. She had just vaccumed with her wind tunnel and didn't want to re vaccum, but I talked her into it. She too was amazed at how much it picked up off her just vaccumed floor. The sensor turned green after a few swipes in one area on her floor, again proves the sensor is working. I am extremely impressed with this vaccum. It has amazing suction and it fits my needs perfectly. Also the washable filters and the 6 year warranty was huge sellers for me. I think I made the right choice.
I was really looking forward to getting this machine.  I've always been a fan of hoover products, but this was a too big for me, and I couldn't get the screws to advance to hold the handle on.

This product was purchased via recommedations on both Amazon and Consumer Reports.  We did not have the vaccum for six weeks before we had to have it serviced.  Sears was the only service rep in our area.  They had the unit for two months and had to replace the entire hose unit ($178 but not paid by us).  I get the unit home, it is working great--suction, etc.  Then I notice dirt in the red tubes and the unit is not performing as well in regards to suction.  I don't see anything in the manual about this issue.  We take the lid off and remove the dirt from the red tubes.  The dirt is packed into the tubs and we had to use a wooden skewer to remove it all, which ended up being over a quart of packed dirt.  Granted, we have two dog but no other vaccum has has this problem before.  I called Hoover to ask if I was doing something wrong.  They said I would have to take it back to the repair people and I absolutely should have not taken it apart.  I will not take it back and risk two months of not having a vaccum.  I will continue to clean the red tubes out until I can't use the machine anymore.  I would never, ever purchase a Hoover product again.

column7: Didn't work out for us at all - going back to Dyson
column8: When our well-worn Dyson DC17 Animal finally started acting up after 4-5 years (they only had a 2 year warranty back then), we were faced with either some expensive repairs or a new vacuum.  Fearing that this may just be the start of a steady stream of repairs, and since we felt we had gotten our money's worth already, I started shopping around for a new replacement.  We were very happy with the Dyson but in the 5 years or so since we bought it, I keep hearing that other manufacturers have caught up with Dyson's performance but at much better prices.  After doing some research and seeing this vacuum rated highly, and from a reputable brand, at half the cost of a new Dyson it seemed a no-brainer to give it a shot.I took it out of the box, put it together, and the wife commented on how slick it looked.  I hauled it upstairs as she wanted to try it out in our bedroom.  Later, from downstairs, I heard her start it up.  My immediate thought was 'wow, that's quiet' even compared to our Dyson which we thought was pretty quiet compared to prior models we had owned.  It ran for awhile, much longer than is normally necessary to vacuum our bedroom floor.  After awhile the wife came downstairs and said 'send it back, I can't use this!'  Thought she was joking.  Nope.  She said it was extremely hard to push and to maneuver.  She suffers from problems with her joins, and pushing this vacuum caused her significant shoulder pain that she still hasn't fully recovered from 2 days later.  To make matters worse, she also said it wouldn't pick up most of the stuff on the carpet.  Surprised by this, I went up and tried it myself.  Sure enough, it was hard for me to push, and at 6'2' 250 lbs, I'm not a small guy.  The Dyson felt like a self-propelled model compared to this, and this one is only a few pounds heavier.  And after all that vacuuming I heard her doing, the collection bin only had some dust and a loose ball of fuzz a little smaller than a baseball.  I spotted a little clump of dog hair on the carpet (we have 2 Golden Retrievers, one reason why we're hard on vacuums) and ran the vacuum over it.  It wouldn't budge.  I reached down and picked it up (it wasn't stuck) and just dropped it back down on the top of the carpet.  I ran the vacuum over it at least 10 times, and it just 'smeared' it out along the carpet but would not pick it up.  A little battery powered hand-vac would have picked that up.  The brush roller was spinning, and it had carpet fuzz embedded all in the bristles, so why it couldn't scoop up a clump of loose dog hair sitting on top of the carpet is quite baffling.Perhaps we got a defective unit -- based on the mostly positive reviews I would have to think so.  Thank goodness for Amazon's easy return process. I suspect that we've been spoiled by Dyson, and rather than experiment with another cheaper unit, I think we'll just bite the bullet and purchase another Dyson Animal model.

I bought this vacuum because I read all the rave reviews.  I am so disappointed in this product.  After I vacuum my carpets, I have to wipe off by hand all the little pieces, such as a length of thread, that it did not pick up.  It keeps shutting off all the time for no reason I can fathom.  I found it extremely awkward to empty.  I'm sending it back, but I'm not happy about it.

On the recomendation of two family members, I bought the Hoover Cyclonic Backless upright vacuum Platinum Collection.  Having used it for about a month now.  I can say I like it alot.I love the bagless feature and the light that tells you if the carpet it still dirty.The only thing I can say would improve this vacuum would be if the hose were longer.  I do use it for steps and would like a longer hose.  I think I can buy an attachment that extends the hose, and will do that.Otherwise it is great and I highly recommend it!

Well... after spending a couple hundred dollars on crap vacuums over the last year or two... I finally deceided to spend that at once and make an investment in a good Vacuum that wouldn't crap out in just a couple of months.  So far... so good!  It removed things I had no idea were in my carpet!  But then again, so did the other less expensive vaccums... but this one promises not too lose suction, and so far it hasn't... but time will tell.  I didn't exactly have, nor did I want to drop $500+ on a Dyson... but had always heard good things about Hoover Windtunnel products... So I was prepared to spend about $350 or so on whatever the top of the line Hoover happened to be putting out at the time.  Just so happens that this Vacuum was it... and I only spent $240 shipped... what a deal!The cycolonic technology is amazing... and I love the fingertip controls... no more bending over to adjust the height settings.  All in all.. I am very pleased... it's a great product that I've confidence in and would gladly buy again.  Can't beat a six year warranty.  In fact, I was so impressed with it I turned around two weeks later and purchased the matching Platinum Carpet Cleaner... and got a great deal on THAT through Amazon as well!  The two compliment each other nicely both in looks, and in cleaning ability... my carpets look NEW!

column7: Still a power machine after almost 2 years
column8: In some negative reviews, you will read how emptying the cannister is messy, or too frequent, and the inner pole needs to be cleaned regularly.  Well, here's why I don't mind any of those.  I love that EVERY time I use my Hoover Cyclonic, it picks up great quantities of stuff on the floor.  The more junk that falls into the trash can, the cleaner the floor.  You just need to stick the cannister into the trashcan, not several inches above, or yes, you will get a cloud of debris everywhere.  Cleaning the removable wand/pole/whatever it is called inside is no problem.  It gets hair and lint wrapped around it, and in a few seconds I get that off, stick it back in, and vacuum away.The suction is still great after owning this machine for almost two years.  The absolute best part about this vacuum is that it works well on hard floors in addition to carpeting.  I find the hard floor setting DOES NOT scatter dirt and dog hair around like other machines.  Even though it's big, it cleans my hard floors far better than any stick vacuum or Swiffer pad.  I have tried other smaller lighter vacuums for my kitchen, but they never seem to completely get everything up.  This Hoover is the only machine I've ever owned that truly picks up on hard floors bigger things like dried leaf fragments and bits of paper to sand and dust particles.  And on carpets?  It cleans them and makes them so fluffy!  Like I said, the proof is in the filled up cannister!  We have a dog, and I wouldn't want to be without my Hoover.We just bought a house, and I took my Hoover Cyclonic over to vacuum the upstairs--all carpeted.  The house is 5 years old, and the carpet looks fine.  However, I don't know what kind of vacuum the former owners used, but my Hoover removed so much fine dirt.  After each room, the cannister was nearly full, and the carpets were noticably cleaner.I am giving my Hoover 4 stars because it has ruined two area rugs.  I should have known better not to run the vacuum over them on the low carpet setting.  The brushes on low carpet setting will eat up your lightweight, smaller rugs (but hard floor setting won't, deep carpet setting seems to be okay too). Also, I hate the button on the front of the cannister that never seems to stay latched.  I had read about this issue in a review before I bought the machine, so I know it is a strange defect.  It's not a huge deal--just means that when you take the cannister out to empty it, the top becomes detached. Nothing spills because the bottom where you empty it is still capped, you just have to close the top lid and hit the button until it clicks again. If it wasn't for this weird thing and the rug killer brushes, I would give my Hoover 5 stars, because I really LOVE how well it sucks crap out of the carpet and off hard floors!Update:  May 10, 2012--Still works like a champ after 3 years.  It still removes tons of dirt and hair from our carpets.

column7: Great suction, messy and awkward to clean.
column8: We have had this vacuum for about one and half years.  It replaced a Hoover self-propelled that died after 10 years.We have a lot of dogs (five at last count). That means dog hair is everywhere, and lots of dust too.  This vacuum does a great job pulling dog hair off carpet.  The four floor height adjustments are easy to access from the handle.  Rolls well.  However, the hose and wand are too short.  Brush and crevice tools are very small.  This vacuum is not well suited for anything but carpeted floors.The worst thing about this vacuum is the dust bin/cyclone system.  Hair gets wrapped around the 'tree'.  The dust bin has to be emptied 4 or 5 times every time we clean. It can be difficult to close and latch the dust bin cover.  Don't forget to reinsert that 'tree'.  We have to go outside to the garage to empty it because there is so much dust that gets all over when emptied into the kitchen waste can.  Dust clings to all of the interior plastic.  Cyclone tubes clog with pet hair.  Cleaning the cyclone tubes requires unscrewing about 8 screws and then blowing it out with an air compressor.There may be better bagless vacuums.  For us, we are going back to bags.

column7: Great vacuum for high pile carpet
column8: I just had new carpet installed and it a very thick, plush carpet.  My old vacuum couldn't handle it and kept shutting down from overheating.  After reading the reviews I decided to try the Hoover Platinum Cyclonic Bagless Upright Vacuum.  I really like this vacuum!  It is pretty easy to push, even on my high pile carpet.  It also worked very well on bare floor.  My puppy is shedding so there was fur everywhere.  This vacuum did a very good job picking up the pet fur on my carpet and upholstery.  I even used it to clean my lampshades and it did a terrific job.  I was amazed at how much dirt it picked up.  I had to empty out the dirt cup a couple times.  My only complaint is that the hose is a little short.  Other than that, I am very pleased with this vacuum and would highly recommend it.

I have used this vacuum for about a year and I am quite happy with it.  I suffer from allergies and researched for a vacuum that would do a great job without a +$500 tag.  If you're in a similar position, see the PROs/CONs of my experience so far, and exaggerated information (IMO) out there:PROs1.  Filtration system, including reusable HEPA filter: This vacuum traps everything, including allergens like dust mites (according to manufacturer's claims).  But I did notice a significant improvement with my allergies after I started using this vacuum.  The washable HEPA filter gives me control over the vacuum's performance by allowing me to clean it and without the need for replacement filters every couple months.2.  Suction system: This is my first Hoover, and I was so impressed with the suction system.  It picked up dust left behind my old vacuum, and even the dust found under the carpet.3.  Relatively quiet motor considering all that is going on.CONs: The 2 issues below are the reason I took away a start from this item, and only gave it 4 out of 5.1.  It is difficult to use the accessories hose because it is kind of short.  It is difficult to vacuum hard to reach places because the hose does not extend too much.2.  Limited reach under furniture: Vacuum canister can get a bit on the way when trying to reach under furniture.EXAGGERATED INFO (IMO): While reading reviews, I came across some users' feedback that made me think twice about whether this item was right for me.  However, I found some of that feedback to be a bit exaggerated.  And that is:1.  Emptying Canister: I kept coming across complaints on emptying the canister.  It is not a big deal.  I just place the canister inside a bag, press the button to release it open, and use my hand (through exterior) to close it.  Yes, it would be nice to click the button again to close, but it is not that difficult.2.  Dealing with dust while Emptying Canister: Honestly, this will happen with any bagless vacuum.  And lint/'stuff' can get stuck can get stuck in tubes, but it is nothing that takes more than 30 seconds to clean.3.  Too Heavy to Move: It is a big vacuum, somewhat bulky, but it is not too heavy given its size.  Perhaps people are not using the right carpet height setting while vacuuming, causing the machine to get stuck on the carpet.Overall, I would purchase this item all over again, and would recommend it to others.  Hope you find this info to be useful.

Over the years I'd bought about 20 vacuum cleaners.  Yes I'm a neat freak.  Even though I just got this vacuum I love it.  I don't mind having to empty the dirt chamber several times while vacuuming and as for cleaning the machine it's no big deal.  My most recent vacuum cleaner purchase was the Dyson ball.  From day one I didn't like it.  I like being able to adjust the height of the vacuum and you can't with a Dyson.  I gave my very expensive Dyson ball to a co-worker. I kept my Dyson mattress tool and my Dyson dusting tool which work with the Hoover if you have the right connector.  I've also got a Kirby bagged vacuum that I also love.

Press dirt cup release button TO short,door open's before I press release button leave's a mess to clean up two out of four times so far.Stretch hose to short,should have longer hose.Other than that power and buttons are fine

This vacuum works great. I can't believe how much dirt was removed from my carpets after I passed this machine over it. Gross! The sucking power is impressive.I did a lot of online shopping and finally decided on this one because of the no loss of suction promise as well as the 6-year warranty.I am glad that I got this one!

column7: The great and the not so good
column8: I give this vacuum 4 stars for two primary reasons: (1) the Hoover is a monster at sucking up pet hair and (2) the Hoover is a monster.We have three dogs and a long-haired cat, and of course they all shed 50 weeks out of the year.  We have had a Meile for the past 16 years -- it has been a great vacuum, but it just didn't seem to have the power to deal with the hair, especially on our wall-to-wall carpet. The hair ate the Meile's power head, and we did not want to spend money to buy an entirely new Meile (~$600).  For everything other than the wall-to-wall carpets, the Meile is still a great vacuum.  So, now we are a two-vacuum, one-car family!On our wall-to-wall carpet, the Hoover has out done itself.  As other reviewers have said, this thing could suck a golf ball through a garden hose, which means it can really suck some hair off the carpet.  It took three complete vacuum events to get the carpets clean and hair free (meaning the canister was full and had to be cleaned out three times).  Our carpets look the best they have since they were installed, not new, but very good considering 4 animals and 2 kids have used them every day for 3 years.  I then used the Hoover in our linoleum kitchen, which usually has dog-hair bunnies running around 2 hours after I vacuum.  Goodbey bunnies!  The Hoover pulled hair out from under the stove without moving the stove.  It cleaned a throw rug we keep in the 'eat in' part of the kitchen so that it looks new.  It did an exceptional job.Now, I have read on Amazon that some of the parts on the Hoover seem a little flimsy. There is some truth to this: the buttons on the vacuum's handle don't have a quality feel to them. The bagless enclosure, however, seems very well built.  It just needs the right touch to get it securely closed, but this is nothing to worry about.  The enclosure is easy to clean out -- the bottom pops open and the contents fall out.  All vacuums get nasty and have to be cleaned, however, and I would guess that this canister will need a more thorough cleaning once very 6 months.  That is to be expected.  The Hoover's filter needs to be cleaned every 6 months, so I will probably clean the whole thing when I clean the filter.  (I clean the Meile about every 6 months.)A couple of other things to note: for a vacuum this powerful, the Hoover is pretty quiet.  Both my wife and I were impressed by this fact when none of the dogs seemed afraid of 'the vacuum monster.'  In a house with as much happening as our house, a quite vacuum is a nice thing to have. Last, the power cord is long, which is nice.  I forgot that with an upright vacuum, you have to manage the cord when you vacuum.  This is a much bigger hassle than it is with the Meile, but it is to be expected.  Finally, the cord wraps around two hard-plastic 'pegs' for storage, just like my parents' Hoover vacuum did in the early 1970s.  It seems odd that a better method for cord management has not been identified, but I guess I can get my 'old fashioned' on with the Hoover.Now for the not so good: the Hoover is big.  I mean really big.  The head is large enough so that it minimizes the number of passes necessary to clean a carpet, but this can also be a liability.  Our house is 100 years old, and the living and dining rooms have lots of wood and lots of nooks and crannies.  The Meile has been great at cleaning these.  There is no way the Hoover will ever be able to do the job of the Meile.  The hose attachment on the Hoover is far too short (laughably so) for much of anything at all.  (Forget about getting it to spider webs on our 10-foot ceilings.) Further, the tools that come with the Hoover are not very useful.  The crevice tool is fine but the upholstery brush is worthless.  This means the Meile will have to continue to be the tool for vacuuming our couches, chairs, and other furniture.  The Hoover will be a welcome addition to cleaning our large area rugs, but that is about it in our more formal living spaces.In sum, I think this would be a great vacuum for a family living in a big open house with some pets keeping the kids company.  The part of our house that meets this criterion will benefit mightily from the Hoover.  It is the best vacuum I have seen when it comes to cleaning wide swaths of carpet that gets a high degree of traffic.  It also sucks pet hair like a fiend.  If you have a lot of woodwork to vacuum the dust from, however, the Hoover will be a disappointment.  Further, if you plan to use the vacuum to clean off your upholstery, there are better tools out there.  All of that said, this vacuum is a solid 4-star product.

column7: Dyson takes a back Seat to this Vacuum
column8: I have had this Vacuum for about 6 months...I have not a had a minutes problem out of it..it picks up everything..has a very strong motor which in turn means great suction power.All the reviews I read that rated this a 1 are off by a long shot..the sensor light on the front of the vac reads 'dirty' or 'clean' works fine..if it says dirty I just keep passing over the spot till it reads clean..gosh thats simple..and one review wrote that they had to replace the sensor twice...not sure of their issue unless they are running the vac into the wall and breaking it...as for cleaning the vacuum one review was saying that it wasnt as simple as opening the bottom and dumping...it has a small piece you turn and pull out every couple of days to thoroughly clean the unit...which they say is a dirty mess...we are not going out to dinner folks...we are cleaning our carpets...its a dirty job..all in all this is the best vac I have owned...the dyson I bought two years ago broke and they wouldnt fix it saying that I damaged it...I went from hardwood floors to carpet and the vacuum sounded like the gears inside broke off a piece...now when you go to carpet it sounds like gear teeth are striping out...I woulnt ever buy on of those over priced plastic toys again...they can make it flashy and cool looking with the ball for a wheel...but the saying for this is 'you can put makeup on a pig ..but you still have a pig' and that is one overpriced Oink!for the money and the performance you cant really beat this vacuum...

column7: Hoover Cyclonic Bagless Upright Vacuum, Platinum Collection, UH70015
column8: My wife and I really like the cleaning power, it cleans way better than our old Eureka! We only replaced the old one because it had become very noisy, but we thought it still cleaned well. The hoover is much quieter which I expected. I cleaned a room with the old vacuum, then immediately followed with the hoover, I nearly filled the canister, wow! The cord is pretty long, maybe 10' longer than the eureka which was already pretty long, so you don't have to worry about finding power in every room. The light on the front is very bright and the power height adjustment is a nice touch. The hose does feel short but does stretch pretty far. Our only complaint was the way the canister is emptied, which is the same way dyson does theirs, it seems to make a mess worse than the cup type. We have only had this for about a month so maybe we will develop a better technique for emptying. We would have given 5 stars if the emptying didn't make a mess, but it isn't that bad and may be our technique. All in all great vacuum and great service regarding shipping from amazon. Oh yeah don't forget the 6 year warranty!

We decided to go with a upright this time, and it was a good choice. The hoover is quiet, easy to get around with and efficient. If I would ask for anything different, it would be an automatic rewind for the long long power cord. The length, of course, is a greaat thing, and rewinding no big problem,An excellent product for the money.

column7: New Hoover not even close to my old one !!!!
column8: I bought this Hoover to replace my old Hoover wind tunnel that died after 7 good years.  I was debating on getting a Dyson over this vacuum but decided to get this Hoover because of past success and the 6 year warranty for the price.  When I received the vacuum it does look and sound impressive. Turning it on it is nice and quiet and light up LED controls. Using it the first time I was disappointed in the lack of suction at the floor,  there was very little to no suction on the brush it has problems picking up small amounts of pet hair stuck to the carpet causing you to go over that same spot over and over. Also while using this vacuum the release that holds the handle upright would not stay engaged causing to fall over while sitting the closet. When trying to empty the canister the release is awkward to empty, then any long hair, strings, or fuzz get wrapped around the center of the canister this has to be removed and every time!!!! Then when you try to close the bottom you have to hold the release button to get it to latch back shut This was just a very bad design !!!!  I used this vacuum twice and then sent it back after using my girlfriends Dyson DC25 !!!*** On a good note, Amazon made it VERY easy to get a prepaid shipping label to get this returned and was very fast in refunding this purchase !!!

Regret buying this vacuum!  I have had it for only a year. It loses suction, The wand is not long enough, the cord gets stiff and it doesn't clean the edges of carpet very well.  Today it stopped working all together!  I was going back and forth between this and a Dyson.  I regret not spending the extra money on the Dyson.  My husband is picking one up tonight and I will have the headache of trying to return this big piece of junk.  Seriously, I wouldn't recommend this to anyone.  Very disappointing!!

column7: only if you have all carpets
column8: Nice vacuum for carpet. Does not clean under furniture, you have to move everything as the handle does not go down much- can't get under tables etc.Only so so for bare floors leaves a lot of debris behind.Attachment are small for such a strong vacuum and the wand is too rigid to get small spaces.Works well on carpet but can't be your only cleaner if you have other flooring.

I absolutely can't say enough great things about this vacuum! First, it arrived quickly and was very simple to assemble. I began vacuuming our area rug and was absolutely AMAZED at how much dirt, dust, etc. came out of it! The suction is unbelievable!! The light indicator gives you piece of mind- It will actually tell you if the spot you're vacuuming is still dirty, and will inform you when it is clean. It's very easy to maneuver and emptying the canister couldn't be more easier!! HIGHLY RECCOMENDED!! Trust me, you won't be disappointed! It's worth every penny!

Like the vaccum.  Works really well.  Wish the hose for tools was longer or had an extension.  Onboard tools really limited - only 2 - a tiny brush and an angle tool.  Don't like the tools or the short hose.  Sucks good though and bagless feature is nice.  Not too heavy and looks pretty.

I bought this vacuum based upon the great reviews it received, and am very surprised that it received so many. The only positive things worth mentioning are that it is fairly quiet in operation, and the power cord is conveniently lengthy. I am very disappointed in the degree of suction with the 'bare floor' setting, and even more disappointed with the attachment hose/tools. The hose is much too short to be of any asset at all, and the absence of extension hoses renders it practically useless for even basic cleaning. The dirt cup and its emptying process is one of the poorest designs I've ever seen; be prepared to re-sweep the floor when you're finished. My old WindTunnel was so much better; it seems as though Hoover went backwards with this model. I wish I would have had the opportunity to try before buying and do not recommend it.

I searched for a new vacuum for a while. I was replacing my 20 year old 80 pound Kirby that had finally died.  I was very interested, at first, in the DYSON products because of the cyclone technology.  With this product you get the same cyclone technology at a much better price.  The first time I used it I was amazed at how much dirt was in my carpets.  The dirty/clean indicator on the front of the vacuum is a big help in reminding you that simply running a vacuum over an area quickly does not really clean it very well. It does a great job on pet hair, I have dog and cat and it picks up the hair easily. The only issue I have with it is that it only came with 2 attachments.  Luckily my many Kirby attachments fit the Hoover hose quite nicely so I can use those instead of searching for and paying extra for other attachments.

column7: I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this vacuum!
column8: OK - I am not the sort of person who gets excited about household appliances, but I am absolutely crazy for this vacuum!  My household includes a large indoor dog (who is very old and sprawls all over the floors all the time), an indoor cat, 2 boys, & 3 adults and I am SO confident that my carpets (and bare floors) are clean after I've used it.  The 40-foot cord is such a convenience I will never accept anything less ever again - I can plug it in just once and vacuum my entire 2000+ sq ft home.  It is very light & easy to push, and the thigh-height handles (front & back) make it super easy for me (or my kids...) to carry up & down stairs.  The height-adjustment controls on the handle are great - no more bending over to turn a knob on the vacuum head (whoever designed those is an idiot), and the suction on this thing is incredible.  The CLEAN/DIRTY sensor seems like a gimmick but I actually find it very useful and often notice that I go back over an area that I would've otherwise thought was already plenty clean.  It could do with an additional extender for the wand, but I just use the one from my old Hoover.  For less than $20 I highly-recommend you invest in the Hoover Turbine Hand Tool - it's well worth it and combined with this vacuum will make you feel like a carpet-cleaning Wonder Woman (or Super Man...).  My husband had bought this vacuum for his office and I borrowed it when our home vacuum started to poop-out.  I liked it a lot but still shopped around and compared this to other vacuums such as the Dysons and could not see that there was any advantage in spending another $300 for the Dyson unless you are extremely name-brand & style-conscious.  It's a vacuum, people, not evening wear.  I thought I'd keep my old vacuum so I'd have one for upstairs & one for downstairs, but after using this one I would not go back to my old vacuum if someone paid me to.  It's going out to the Goodwill.  I've been using this vacuum for a few months now and no problems at all.  I've just bought one for my mom, too and I'm certain that she will LOVE, LOVE, LOVE it as much as I do (and her house will be cleaner!)

Having reviewed the reviews on amazon for both the hoover and the dyson I decided on the hoover.  One thing frequently mentioned in the reviews was comparison of the cleaning using the old vacuum with the new one, I did not find that helpful because if you are looking at a new vacuum it usually means the one you have isn't working well and i would expect the new one to pick up more dirt.  The issues that made me pick the hoover was the deficients pointed out with the dyson, for that kind of money I don't want to hear about problems with hose / attachments.Why did I pick the hoover?  Well it's got a 6 yr warranty and its $130 cheaper than the dyson (same price at walmart).  Why do I think I made the right choice? well it has a 6 yr warranty, cheaper than dyson and my rugs stay cleaner longer (yeah).  Instead of 2 or more times a wk i vacuum once a week and the rugs still look good even with a hairy dog and a teenager.  time will tell if this last fingers crossed!!!There are some things that could be better like the hose doesn't stay put when using the attachment and the book doesn't address attaching the hosethe designation for clean and dirty, not sure what the need is for that would prefer they spent the money on more attachments like a hand held for the stepsmy other hoover had an auto cord rewind which i really liked but not on this machine guess that the price you pay for the longer cord.  the screws to attach the handle are not properly placed.Suction is important but let us not forget about workmanship!!********update***********************************************looks like I spoke to soon, after less than one month of use this is being returned, the rollers stop working and I don't know why and don't care, for this kind of money on a vacuum I not playing MS Fitit this soon.  Still love Amazon, make returns a piece of cake.

Poerful vacum that does a really good job. Fairly quiet (important). Four settings for type of floors (bare floors, low-med.high rugs) - great There is also a digital sensor that tells if your floor is dirty or clean. My only complaint is that it does not come with enough tools.(I would have liked to see an extension hose and a furniture tool)

I did hours of research trying to find the perfect vacuum for my rather demanding needs, I have multiple cats and a dog in a house with wall to wall carpeting and fiancee with allergies. Vacuuming in an every day task in our home so we wanted something Heavy Duty. I'm happy to report that I've had this vacuum for 6 months now and vacuum almost every day with fantastic results.The vacuum has excellent suction power, it made my carpets look new again the first time I went over them. The long cord means I can vacuum almost the entire first floor of my house without having to change outlets. The hose is a bit shorter than I'm used to but still has excellent suction power and the upholstery brush actually gets pet hair off the furniture unlike every other vacuum I've ever used.It does have a problem, which for me is not enough to make less than a 5 star rating but could cause a problem for someone else. The dustcup is rather small, and we pretty much empty it after each room. If you are not diligent about noticing when the cup is full and emptying it you will lose suction and get dirt and debris in the tunnel chamber and you'll have the very messy job of pulling out by hand. However if you are good about properly emptying it, you can empty the dust cup normally and not lose suction.Overall I feel this was a great purchase and one I would gladly recommend to friends and family.

I purchased this after reading it's awesome reviews, and I was really disappointed. At first, it lifted the carpet off of the ground!! I loved the intense suction...but it didn't last. Before I was even finished with the first use, the suction power had completely vanished. I tried cleaning it, looking for holes in the tube, EVERYTHING!! But nothing worked. I had to send this item back, and was informed that it could take FOUR weeks to receive my refund. What am I supposed to do now?!?!! I will never buy Hoover again.

column7: Not a good choice for hard floors
column8: My wife bought this about 3 years ago because she used on at a friend's home.  I used it today on hard floor for mostly dog hair.  The way the air exits the unit it creates airborne hair and dust.  This is especially a problem around the wood stove where there is often ash on the ash fender of the stove.  The fender is about 6' above the floor and when the vacuum is near the fender it blows ash from the fender and also from the floor into the air creating more work for dusting of furniture in the room.  With dog hair it also will blow hair from the floor into the air where it settles on furniture.At 25', the power cord is too short and there is a 90 degree fitting at the bottom rear of the unit which you often hit with your foot when disengaging the rotating brush.  This creates low suction which can go unnoticed.It does have an easy to empty canister and a good filtration system.  However the filtration system is not much good when so much duct is blown into the air by the exhaust.No, I would not recommend this to a friend.

I purchased the Dyson DC25 a couple years ago and am still very happy with it. I have 4 dogs and have always battled dog hair on my carpet and furniture. This vacuum does an amazing job of removing it.Great suction. Sucks up the hair without having to go over the area again and again. Very easy to empty and clean. Very lightweight and manuverable. I have had alot of vacuums over the years, some high end, and none compair to the Dyson. When the time comes to replace it, I will purchase another Dyson. Well worth the price.....  Jenny,  Bryan,Texas
Stopped working a few months ago and sent to Dyson for repair. Now again it will not stay on.  If you need a reliable vacuum do not buy this one it is not worth the money.

I ordered this vacuum after reading great reviews on it. I previously had a Eureka canister vacuum. I have to say, the one thing I miss, is being able to just go right under a table with the canister vac. That's the only thing I am not as crazy about with the Dyson. They do have the wand which you pull out to use to go under tables, couches and do stairs etc. Just that that is one more thing you have to stop and do. Otherwise, love this vacuum! The ball technology is neat! It pivots the vac to go left or right. Very easy to maneuver. Suction is great, and love the see thru collection container for the dust. Easy to empty. Really like the foot peddle that you press to put the vacuum in use. Glad there is nothing you have to buy for this vacuum. Just rinse out the filter, and empty cup, no bags to purchase. I would have liked it if the button to turn it on were more towards the top, but it is placed mid way down right next to the button that you press for the brush to turn or not for when doing floors. All in all, I would highly recommend. I have 2 dogs, and it does a great job of sucking up all the pet hair.

We purchased this vacuum about 2 years ago and I still love it.  We have one large dog that unfortunately sheds a lot.  This picks up hair in the carpeted areas that our other vacuums had missed. We have carpet, hardwoods, tile and area rugs.  The dyson does great on everything but one area rug.  It is a long shag type rug and the dyson just has too much suction for it.  Even turning off the beater brush, it is very hard to move forward.  You can only pull the vacuum so we have to use a canister model - not dyson. Too much suction is not a bad thing!  The bagless feature is wonderful - you can see when you need to dump the canister since it is clear and you can dump it more often since you aren't replacing a bag every time.  The ball design is easy to maneuver and does great around baseboards and furniture.  I clean the filters about twice a year and it is simple and easy.  So far this vacuum has been maintance free.  Yes, it is expensive but it will is more than worth the cost.  This does go on sale so watch for those.  I have had other uprights(self-propelled) and canisters and they don't begin to compare to this vacuum.
super vac. very powerful gets animal hair up better than old vac. by far.6 more words 6 more words needed

Although I'm not sure anything could match the rather incredible picture painted by their commercials, I found the Dyson to be a sturdy and effective cleaner. The documentation is a little lacking, but the machine itself is great.

column7: How did I ever live without a Dyson Animal?
column8: I love my Dyson Animal. I was flabbergasted at how much fur and hair this machine sucks up. I have three northern breed dogs and I have long hair.  The first time I ran this machine I pulled out 12 canisters of hair and dirt and I had just vacuumed with my old Kirby machine. After several months of using this I get about 1/2 to 2 canisters worth of hair out every other day. My allergies and my dog's allergies have subsided tremendously! My house has a cement slab as a floor so I need the carpet to keep the house warm. Thank goodness the Dyson Animal can keep my carpet free of debris and hair. I love that the canister keeps the dust and odor confined. With my old Kirby you could see the dust floating around (even with a HEPA bag) and smell the doggy odor. The Dyson Animal vacuum is terrific and the ball feature makes it so easy to maneuver!!!
A fantastic machine.  It is easy to use and the pick up is great.  Cleaning the machine is easy, too.  it is just a great vacuum.

That's right! My husband loves the way the dysentery works so much he vacuums often. It's always amazing to see how much dirt and let hair is picked up even when the floor looked clear prior to vacuuming!

We've never owned a Dyson before so the ball feature was completely lost on me until I used it.  This vacuum turns on a dime and makes vacuuming an easy and pleasant task. The attachments being stored on the vacuum are very handy and allow easy switching from floor vacuuming to edging, fans, etc.  The mini-turbine very effectively removed a tremendous amount of cat hair and dust from my couches.  I love how easy it is to remove the dust and hair from the collection container.  Sometimes hair wants to stick in there, but a chopstick will easily take care of any stubborn remnants.  I gave this five stars for ease of use and effective cleaning power.

Very happy with this vacuum, it works very well, is easy to maneuver, and I love all the attachments!  My only complaint is that the attachment wand has to be extended completely to use it, so if you are trying to use one up close, like on a table, you are holding onto a 3 foot extension no matter what.  Other than that, it works great.

column7: How do I hate thee, let me count the ways...
column8: I gave this two stars because it does, after all, pick up dirt off the floor, which is the main function of a vacuum cleaner.  But if you want to do anything else, it is very awkward.  As an engineer, I appreciate an innovative and elegant design, but this is neither.  It is different, but that doesn't make it better.1) The most annoying part of this vacuum cleaner is the handle for the tools.  It has been pre-determined that you will want a three foot long handle.  If you want to use it for a closer task like dusting, you can remove the handle and use just the hose, but gone is the option to use one or two short sections as the job demands.  Combine this with a stiff hose that fights you constantly, and cleaning the stairs becomes a real fight.2) The hose is a reasonable length (a good hard stretch will get you about 8 feet), but you need to somehow anchor the unit behind some furniture to get more than about three feet out of it (remember that the handle itself is three feet long).  Just to put the crevace tool on and clean the corners of the floor, you need to yank on the hose hard enough to drag the vacuum cleaner with you the whole time.3) The hose is incompatible with any other tools or hose extensions that you might have around from previous vacuum cleaners.  Got a tool that has always worked for a special task (refrigertator coils, for example)? Forget about it.  Duct tape is your best hope of making it work.4) The poorest options for a dust brush I have ever met.  You get two options: too big, and too small.  What was wrong with the do-all 3 inch round brush that everyone else uses? I'm not sure, but now you get the cute little retractable one inch by two inch brush on the end of the crevace tool (while fighting the hose) or the eight inch brush that I haven't found a use for yet.  Want to use your old 3 inch brush?  See comment #3.  And that eight inch brush finds itself in the closet, because there's nowhere to store it on-board.5) The little clip on the cord is ineffective and difficult to use.  What was wrong with the clamp molded into the back of the plug, like everyone else uses (except for the fact that someone else invented it)?  This separate clip is hard to operate, and the point-contact clip doesn't grab anywhere on the round wire.  At best, it clamps around the wire, and then the cord is loose, and catches on things as you wheel past them.  Just dumb.6) The clear dust bin is good for seeing when it is full, but it is dificult to empty.  Pressing one button is convenient, but you then find that the dust bunnies and hair picked up off the floor get caught on the rubber seal, and need to be cleaned out by hand anyway.  After about a dozen uses, the bin becomes so dusty that it is essentially translucent, not transparent, which will drive most clean-freaks nuts.It does actually have a few clever ideas going for it.  The washable filters are very useful, and fairly easy to remove and check/wash.  I like that you can turn off the beater brush when you need to, unlike my old vacuums.  And yes, it does corner like a Ferrari.  I'm not quite sure why my vacuum cleaner needs to perform like a super car, but it does.  Perhaps a clever ploy to get men to vacuum?In short, I applaud Dyson for trying some new ideas, but they went overboard, and fixed things that weren't broken.  An innovative design would have employed a new approach to solve a problem.  An elegant design would do that in a simple way that would cost less and be easier to use.  This is neither.  Instead, it seems to be an ego-stroke for the designer, to see how many things they could do differently, so as to impress the consumer - which would be OK if the resulting product was better. This one's just more expensive.

column7: Dyson picks up a lot more than my Hoover
column8: The first time I used this vacuum, I was impressed with how much it picked up and how quickly the canister filled.  However, they could have included a better manual for assembly and use.  I thought I would never get it put together and then had to struggle with trying to release the wand attachment.  The vacuum itself feels very flimsy (seems almost all plastic) and I am now concerned with how long it will last.  The most expensive vacuum I have ever bought

column7: 2011 BLACK FRIDAY advice:  buy at Target or Dyson directly
column8: This item is being closed out at Target.  If purchased through the discover card link (discovercard dot com/shopping) you'll get an additional 10% off... which makes this item $399... much better price than here on Amazon.  Alternatively, dyson dot com is offering up to $170 off their online vacuums and you'll receive additional email discounts if purchased directly from dyson.Happy shopping and happy holidays!

We have a cat.  She sheds. A lot!  They call this Dyson 'The Animal'.  It is!  You can just see a whole cat's worth of hair filling up the visible chamber.  Way better than the Kirby we have been using.My wife has arthritis to the max.  The Kirby was HEAVY.  This thing with its ball just steers and glides effortlessly.  No bags to replace.  you can wash everything so it does not get that old vacuum smell.  It completely disassembles.It comes with a handy attachment for doing carpeted stairs.  We use it regularly.  The hose is easy to dispense and store.This vacuum is probably the best value on the market today.

I was a bit hesitant to pay so much money for a vacuum cleaner, but if you want the best, you have to fork out a little more.  The 'ball-technology' is really nice for maneuverability, it's a fairly powerful vacuum, and the attachments are nice.  The dust bin is really nice as well, I like how the bottom opens up (dumping its contents) with the push of a button.

column7: The answer if you have a pet!
column8: Our oldest child went to college, so we attempted to fill the void with a cute rescue puppy that looks like a golden retriever. Now that our special puppy has grown, he sheds like crazy. I cannot believe how well the Dyson Animal can suck up every trace of hair that 'Fluffy' leaves behind. Our last vacuum cleaner was a top of the line Oreck, but it didn't have near the suction that the Dyson has. I'm very happy with our Dyson!

column7: best vacuum a house of long haired girls and heaps of pets has ever had
column8: We were burning through vacuums about every year even with all the maintenance and care we could have given because we had a carpeted place, 3 cats, one guinea pig and 4 long haired girls in one house. The motors  on other vacuums would clog and burn because there are parts that just cannot be reached for cleaning and it was becoming expensive to replace these middle of the line vacuums yearly. We read the reviews and bucked up to get the 'expensive' dyson and have had it for more than 5 years. Considering that it has no bags, is easy to maintain, cleans up things youd never imagine reside in your carpet and can handle all the hair without losing power, its actually the cheap alternative. LOVE IT!!!!

column7: Best investment I've made since purchasing my beloved labrador!
column8: I'm so thrilled with this vacuum I might faint from the excitement!  Despite some of the negative comments regarding the Dyson spreading dog hair around I bought it anyway.  I think anyone who has that problem is failing to push the button that disables the spinning brush.  I watched dog hair being sucked up across the floor as if attracted to a magnet.  Retiring the oreck immediately.
This machine is made cheaply.  The ball sticks and it is awkward to use.  It moves a few feet then you have to lift it. I am 5'2' and am way to tall to use it.  It is terrible.

I've heard all the hype about Dyson for years.  Wanted one but didn't think that it was worth the cost.  IT IS!This has to be the best vacuum I have ever owned.  I actually performed the Dyson test.  Vacuumed my home with my year old bag-less Dyson style name brand vacuum cleaner (which actually has a light which signifies when the carpet is 'clean') and then vacuumed with my Dyson.  I could not believe how much dirt was left behind.  I own a dog and this vacuum is able to pick up the dog hair-no problem!The vacuum goes from carpet to hard floors without adjustments and is a true time saver.  On top of all that, it's light, compact and easy to carry around.My opinion?  Buy the Dyson...you will not be dissapointed.

column7: Dyson DC25 Animal Ball-Technology Upright Vacuum Cleaner
column8: I really like the vacuum. It is lightweight and has a small footprint in my small utility closet. Does a great job picking up the animal hair. Easy to empty the dirt container. I am still getting used to the ball mechanics-- I try to use it like a conventional vacuum out of habit-- once I adjust to that, I think I will like it even better. I also struggle a bit with the handle when I want to use the wand/hose-- I don't quite have the hang of detaching the handle mechanism but I suspect it is me and not the machine. I would recommend getting and using the machine before ordering any attachments as you may not need them all-- it comes with several attachments which I find is adequate for me. Also, the supplier I used required a signature on delivery which I didn't realize at first. If I had known that, I would have used a different shipping address-- if this matters to you, find out before ordering if a signature is required.

column7: Dc-25 Animal is not user friendly
column8: I have not found the Dyson Vacuum to be user friendly.  I am elderly and I had to tug to get the filters out to clean.  The instructions says one should allow the top filter to dry 24 hours.  Three days later, my filter was not dry and due to needing to vacuum, used a hair dryer for a quick dry. The hair dryer burned holes in the filter, which had to be replaced.  The help line contact persons (2)could not give reason why the vacuum caused ruts in my carpets. My experience with two help line persons resulted in no resolutions of my problems.  The vacuum does have fairly good suction.  My opinion is that there are better vacuum cleaners which cost a whole lot less.

I've tried them all. Uprights, canisters, robotic, bagged,  bag-less and even an industrial back pack that made me look like something out of Ghost Busters. Nothing beats my Dyson Animal. I put mine through a test that borders on cruel and certainly qualifies as stupid. I didn't clean the filter A for over a year. It was covered with pet hair and dirt. My bad. There is a filter B a s well. News to me! I've had the vacuum for almost 3 years and didn't know there was a filter in the ball. Really stupid. I cleaned both filters with water as directed. Voila! They are as good as new. The point is that even with my neglect and abuse the vacuum never even hiccuped. I have two dogs that shed constantly by the way. It was working like  a charm the entire time. I have repented of my evil treatment of this loyal machine. It will be maintained properly from now on. The moral is that nothing short of a nuclear explosion can stop this vacuum - even then I wonder. I'm building a shrine to my Dyson Animal vacuum.

My home has turned into a veritable zoo.I have a 5 year old, 8 year old, and an 11 year old and they all love their furry little creatures. I do not. I am mildly allergic to cats and dogs and the dander and garbage that these disgusting animals attract to them. But I can't tell my kids no because that would break their heart.We have a golden retriever, a lab, 3 cats, and a parakeet. The hair from the dogs is bad enough, but the cats and the bird feathers in the air makes it feel like you are living in a barn. Until we bought this Dyson.I have to have my carpets professionally shampooed and cleaned every month for $200. Yes, it is expensive. We bought the Dyson shortly after having them professionally shampooed. It was absolutely disgusting what this vaccum picked up. Hair, fur, finger nails, dirt, and who knows what all the other crud was. At any rate this vacuum SUCKS, and in the best way possible.I would prefer this vacuum to having my rugs professionally cleaned, because the proof is there. It works better than the pros and all their smelly detergents and expensive $200 sessions.

My sons ran over the cord by accident.  It ripped the cord.  We have 4 vacumm repair shops in town.  Dyson does not allow them to fix vacuum.  I need to drive one hour!!!!  to the closest dealer authorized to fix it!! Check before you buy it!!!

After bein a faithful Oreck owner for 20 years, I did alot of research before switching to a Dyson.  I purchased this model because of our lovably but hairy golden retriever.  This vacuum, like others have said, really picks up the dog hair.  I have never owned a bagless vacuum before, but was rather sickened by what the Dyson picked up after its first use.  I'm a bit of a clean freak, so finding that much dust/dirt/doghair lurking in my carpets was a bit disturbing.What I don't like about my new vacuum are the attachments.  I find them extremely awkward to use.  The hose is stiff and it is hard to reach any distance without the vacuum ramming into the back of you.  I have used it for one month now and have decided to keep it just due to the suction power.  But I will continue to use my old Oreck attachments when needed.  Whenever I try my Dyson attachments I get very irritated.

I've had to send my DC25 back in TWICE for repairs.  They will not even help with finding you a loaner.  Completely unacceptable for the price.  While I feel that the suction is just GOOD, it doesn't live up to all the hype; the vacuum is composed mostly of plastic and we've had problems with the brush/nosepiece which keeps snapping, the wand, and other plastic pieces.  Whenever I pick up the vacuum, the nosepiece just falls down vertically when you pick it up.  Wand is very 'un-user-friendly' and cannot be easily detached without some effort.  When you DO get the wand off, it's bulky, and doesn't work well on most pieces of standard furniture.  I have another vacuum that I paid $100 for (Panasonic) which I use in concert with my DC25.  The vacuum is also awkward to place into the upright, locked position, and I find myself using strong jerking actions to get the vacuum locked and unlocked (really bad for those folks with orthopedic issues like tennis elbow).  The vacuum is heavy despite the abundance of plastic used in its' frame.  Also, the canister is miserably small; I only have a 2700 square foot home and have to empty the canister at least two times when I'm doing a marathon house cleaning session.  The canister is easy to empty, and unline the other negative review I read, the canister comes apart in two pieces so that you never have to reach your hand inside of it to empty it.Overall, it's a very expensive piece of equipment.  I would look to other leading manufacturers of high end vacuum cleaners before I would buy this again.  Once you buy it, it's yours.... and you're stuck with it!

Already own one Dyson, so getting a second one was not a difficult decision. As I have long known, you get what you pay for.This purchase was prompted by a new addition to our family --- a furry dog that is cute beyond belief, but leaves a trail of fuzz everywhere she goes.We had a popular but less expensive brand name upright at our place and it just wasn't cutting it. Aside from being heavier and having a bag, it only picked up a portion of the stuff from the pup and it didn't have much reach when using the wand.This machine (like my other Dyson) is a dream. It is lightweight and extremely portable. It has a long telescoping wand that reaches 16 feet and comes with a full complement of accessories. It self adjusts to all floor surfaces and finishes. I also get a lot of sand at the house I'm using it at and it picks up even the grains that get stuck between the floorboards. The suction that this machine generates is like a tornado. It maneuvers nicely on its pivot and gets into all sorts of tight and inconvenient nooks and crannies. It has two permanent filters that take little effort to clean under a running tap and air dry about once a month. The waste bin opens with a quick touch and disposal involves putting the bin over a waste can.The gross but good thing is that the clear container exposes all the icky things the Dyson has collected. For the heck of it, after I vacuum I empty the bin and do a second pass over the clean rugs, floors, and furnishings. Nothing gets collected the second time around so I know it's cleaning thoroughly.This vac may not be for everyone because it is pricey, but you do get what you pay for when it comes to a Dyson.

You see what I did there in the title? ;-)But seriously it is the best vacuum I have ever owned. Worth every penny!  I live in a good sized apartment with a dog so my place needs to be vacuumed every weekend to stay clean. It not only is incredibly easy to use and maneuver but I have never had one that works so well. For comparison, when cleaning kitchen floors, typically I'd have to roll over dog hair, lint, whatever to get it and sometimes it wouldn't even go up. With the DC25 I can be 6-12 inches away from dust, lint, dog hair, etc and it will get pulled into it.My only regret is I waited so long to get one fearing it was all over priced hype. Boy is my face red now. I should have gotten one years ago.

I haven't provided many product reviews, but thought that I should with the Dyson DC25 Animal.  My wife and I have a Newfoundland dog, those who know the breed know that dog hair and dog slobber are fashion accessories in our house.  The DC25 can't help with the slobber, but it does a terrific job in cleaning up the hair.  Our point of reference in vacuums is a Big Vac canister we bought from Jeff Campbell's Clean Team back in the early '90s and an Oreck XL upright we bought about 12 years ago.  We still have both and have been able to compare the three side-by-side.  Here's what we like about the DC25:The ball - When I saw the ball on the TV commercials, I thought it was a gimmick.  I've found it does help in moving the vacuum around.  But more importantly, I found that the ball carries the weight, rather than the beater bar.  This is important when it is used on plush carpets (which is in a finished basement) as it makes the vacuum easy to move on the thicker carpet.  I broke the fan chamber on the Oreck using it on the plush carpeting, because the fan chamber is also the mounting point for the handle.  With all the weight of the vacuum on the base/beater bar, it was difficult to push on the thicker carpet and the stress from the handle broke the fan chamber.  When I had it repaired, the owner of the shop asked if I had sucked in a hairpin or bobbypin, as he has seen the same damage from that.  He also told me that there was no way he knew to provide the adjustment needed to prevent this from happening again.  It wasn't an expensive repair, but I didn't expect that kind of problem with the Oreck.  The Big Vac did OK on the plush, but the DC25 was much easier to use on the plush (this is more a canister vs. upright discussion in my view).The beater bar motor shut off - We haven't had a vacuum with this feature, but it is very handy when moving from carpet to hardwood.  This reduces the risk of damaging the floor (although with a big dog it would be hard to tell what is from her and what is from the vacuum).  It also means you don't need to change the hose-end attachment from the beater bar head to the solid floor head, as with the Big Vac.The suction - We started looking at the DC25 after a Rainbow demonstration in our house.  I agree with the Rainbow guys, suction/air flow is key to effective vacuuming.  We don't care for a canister vacuum (we used the Big Vac for a number of years before the Oreck and much preferred the upright Oreck).  However, I can't see spending over $2K for a new Rainbow, even $1K for a used one is too much in my view.  Also, we do have a couple of friends who have had Rainbows in the past, they stopped using them after a few years because the water feature (adding water before you start, thoroughly cleaning out the water basin after finishing) was very inconvenient for them.  The DC25 has great suction and seems to maintain it as the canister fills.  A word of warning, if there is a loose thread in the carpet or rug, the DC25 will find it.  I ran it over a throw rug, which I had done with the Oreck many times over the past few years.  The DC25 sucked a loose thread up into the beater bar and I had about 5 feet of thread wrapped around it in a matter of a second or two.  This brings me to the next point,The beater bar - I really like the way you can easily remove the beater bar.  Use a coin to turn a button to unlock the side plate, rotate the side plate, and the bar slides out.  With long dog hair, it will get wrapped around the bar.  By being able to remove the bar, it makes it very easy to get the hair (and the carpet thread mentioned above) off.  With both the Big Vac and the Oreck, you need to pull the hair off the bar with it in the machine or do some amount of disassembly.  I would leave the machines assembled and use a utility knife to cut the hair between the brushes, then pull it off.  I would need to disassemble both of them a few times a year, as the hair would be wrapped around the bearings on the ends and start to jam the bar, which resulted in the belt not turning (you can smell the rubber heat up when this happens).  This has not been a problem with the DC25.Noise - the DC25 is much quieter than the Oreck and about the same as the Big Vac.  As a tangent to the noise level, the Oreck seems to generate a sound frequency that is disturbing to the dog, as she stays as far away as she can from it, even to the point of jumping over furniture.  It is an amazing sight to see 115 lbs. of airborne dog.  This has not been a problem with the DC25 or the Big Vac, the dog stays well grounded.  Newf owners will concur that these dogs have a talent for holding down the floor.Other reviews have mentioned that the cord is too short and the canister too small, we see these two as minor inconveniences.  For the main floor of our house (2,000 sq ft) we need to use three outlets to reach everywhere with the DC25.  When we need to move the plug to cover the next area, the cansiter is also dumped, so these complaints are not a big concern for us.  Another concern mentioned is in dumping the canister.  The bags in the Oreck and Big Vac aren't difficult to change, but we haven't found that dumping the DC25 canister to be a problem.  Push the gray release button and the canister comes off, hold it over your trash container and push the red button and the bottom of the canister pops open.  We haven't noticed any significant amount of dust being put in the air from this, but I imagine that could happen.  Also, the bags for the Big Vac are available online only, the Oreck bags are available online or at an Oreck store; you need to keep a supply in your home for any bag-based vacuum.  Bag availability is not a problem with the DC25.Our only recommendation to Dyson is to add a light to the head, the Oreck has that and it is a nice feature when you are in areas that are poorly lit.Some may be concerned about the price, ours was delivered at about $500.  This is about what we paid for the Oreck in '99, the Big Vac was about $400 in '91.  For us, this seems about the right price point for a premium vacuum.  A relative bargin compared to the Rainbow ;-)

I have six big dogs, and I've wanted this vacuum for a long time. Bought it recently, and at first I was 100% enthusiastic. I vacuumed my living room first with my old vac (Sebo) and then did it with the Dyson. I couldn't believe how much dirt the old vac left behind. So even though the electric cord was very short, I thought it was a great vac. Then as I used it more I discovered that the size of the bin that collects the dirt is so small that I had to stop often to empty it. Ok, not a huge deal. Inconvenient, but it was really getting things clean. The problem came with using the attachments on the wand. That was initially ok, but then one of them got stuck. I mean really stuck. No matter what I did I couldn't get it off. I had to get my neighbor, and he had a terrible time getting it off. He works for a sawmill, so it wasn't a matter of not being strong. He put it back on, and it immediately got stuck again. Ok, for that much money I can't call my neighbor every time I want to get an attachment off. I took it back and bought one of the Hooever WindTunnel vacs for under $200, and it works every bit as well as the Dyson, plus it has a long cord and you press a button and the cord retracts itself. And the bin for the dirt is larger. So you decide - if you want to spend $250 more for the Dyson name, go for it. Otherwise, I'd say there is no need to waste your money. Very disappointed in the Dyson!

I don't know... I'm thinking the people who are so excited and love this machine are just not willing to admit they made such a terrible mistake in spending so much money on it.  Misery must love company, eh?  Well, I'm not ashamed to admit I made a mistake, and I want to prevent others from doing the same.  This vacuum is NOT worth your hard-earned money.1) Bagless vacuum = DISGUSTING.  Now, I know that's not entirely a Dyson thing... but at least a Dirt Devil doesn't make me fork over $500 to get grossed out.  Not only that, this thing needs dumped so often, it's ridiculous, and the hair turns into a huge matted dirty mass around the middle of the canister that you have to dig out with your hands.  Ugh, so nasty.2) It's poorly made.  Chintzy.  Even when you just set it upright and try to click it into place it feels... fragile.  Not solid at all.  It's just so cheap-feeling.  I could not believe it costs as much as it did.  There can't be $20 worth of plastic in the whole thing.  I have a kid's toy Dirt Devil that feels more well-made than this.3) The attatchments are terrible and mine actually quit working for some mysterious reason (unable to find any sort of blockage, etc.) so now I don't even have a usable hose/attatchments at all.4) It's difficult to maneuver.  Granted, I was coming from a Kirby, that was motorized and helped push itself about... but really?  You have to hold the Dyson Animal up as you are using it.  There's no base to stand on.  No 'back' to it... no back wheels or stand.  Again, not solid whatsoever.  So you're pushing it around AND holding it up at the same time.  It's a pain.  Don't dare let it go to pick up a toy or something on the floor... kerplunk!  Over it falls.  That is, unless you try to push it upright first.  Good luck with that, though.  Click.  Click.  CLICK.  Omg why won't it just STAND UP??5) Roller ball fail.  That is all.  It gets nasty too and it's difficult to clean.  And what is up with that filter in there?  Really?  There's a filter in the ball.  So... that must mean there's... air... going through the ball?  Indeed.  What is that filter for exactly?6) No carpet height settings.  Why?  It wants us to believe that all carpets need the same amount of suction?Bottom line, DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY.  You deserve better than this.  Your money should be worth more to you than this piece of junk.

We have a baby and long-haired cats, and have spent years wrestling and griping about crappy vacuums. This Dyson works perfectly on our wood floors, tile floors, and carpet. It has a great extending arm to get into corners, under couch cushions, and anywhere else you may see a rogue Cheerio. Just point in the general direction and the Dyson will suck it across the floor like its using The Force. Yes, it's pricey. And yes, it is totally worth it!

This vacuum absolutely disgusted me within 5 minutes of using it. I can't believe what my Riccar and Kirby were not picking up. For all those people who complain about the small reservoir, you must be kidding me. It is so easy and painless to empty it and I now realize that if my other vacs were picking up half what the dyson does (which I doubt), I did not change the other bags near enough.  Instead of the dirt going into a dark hole, I can see when it's time to empty it.I have two cats and two dogs. The animal attachment was completely worth it when I saw how much stuff and hair it lifted off my couches.Bottom line, this vacuum is awesome and worth it.

column7: This thing Sucks, and it does it with the least effort.
column8: Okay, I usually do not write reviews unless one of three things happen:1. It works great.2. It sucks.3. I used it for a long time and need to balance the other reviews on the product.Since the DC 25 animal uniquely satifies 1 and 2, I thought I needed to provide a review.Background:I had a Hoover Windtunnel (4 years old) and recently moved to a new home. When using my vacuum, I noticed that it was tough to move across the carpet and that it was not picking up all the artifacts on the floor. I took the vacuum apart and confirmed clear hosing and agitator. I also confirmed the wheels worked on the vacuum.  The reason for the difficulty for carpet was the strong sucking power (it pulled the carpet/not the dirt), the old wheels and (a downgraded) carpet.The Test:Now, I found this vacuum for sale at a local store.  Having a great return policy, I decided to make this purchase and put the vacuum to the test.Not only did it pick up everything that the Hoover did not pick up from the same area rug and carpet, it was done effortlessly (by both the vacuum and the person pushing it). The AMOUNT of dirt, hair and lint it picked up was unbelievable.Result:The ball technology lowered the center of gravity of the vacuum, eased the passes on the carpet and improved maneuverability. The vacuum really sucked (in a good way). My wife loves it.I have never tried an Oreck or similar. All I know is that I am very pleased with the purchase.CONS!!!The only CON I have is the canister. It is small. Not only did it fill quickly. Once it is partially full, it does not pick up the finer dirt and dust. Once the canister is emptied, I passed through the same are to get more dirt. This was after our first experience with the vacuum. I figured once we use this vacuum more often, the rate to empty the canister will drop. I do not think this CON satisfies a drop in a star.

This sweeper easily picks up dog hair and the canister is easy to empty. I have a lot of trouble using the nozzle attachment for steps.  It's plastic so it's light-weight, but it feels flimsy.  I don't think it will last a long time.

Don't even think twice, just go get one. The belt on my Kirby Generation V broke a couple of days ago, and I couldn't find a replacement locally (I live in a rural community). My cleaning person was here today with her bagless vacuum, which picked up more than my Kirby did. I thought I would look at the Dyson both on line and in the stores. Finally found the Animal, brought it home, and vacuumed where the cleaner had vacuummed only a couple of hours before. I vacuummed 3 area rugs and a hallway...then I had to empty the canister! I can't believe the dirt & hair it collected. I am completely sold. Anyone want to buy a Kirby?

The best part is how easy it goes from carpet to tile!!! Light enough, maneuverable enough, does a good job, easy to move around and store. I usually don't enjoy getting the vacuum out for a small job, and keep buying those small cordless, that less like a month, but this one - no problem. I remember using the older model at my friends house and remember it being heavier. Looks like this model is upgraded and much lighter! Pricey? Yes. But there is an expression - we are not reach enough to buy cheap thing!

column7: About the same Dyson that I remember
column8: I had an old Dyson Animal that I decided to give to a friend after 5 years of problem-free service.  So when choosing my new vacuum, I leaned towards another Dyson and decided on the Animal Ball since I wanted to see what 5 years of innovation would turn out.  The verdict after a month of use is that this thing seems over-engineered to perform a simple task...guess I got what I asked for.  The good is that it is very light, can turn at almost a 90 degree angle with ease, seems to do an adequate job of cleaning, and the canister although small is big enough for at least 4-5 cleanings before it has to be emptied (someone said they emptied theirs 3 or 4 times per cleaning and I don't see how that can be).  The bad is that it seems fragile--not the material, but the way it is engineered and put together.  The canister doesn't have a tight fit as my old one; I'm pretty sure this is by design but it still doesn't give me a warm and fuzzy feeling.  Every time I recline the vacuum, I'm a little wary of the release mechanism breaking.  I guess most of my criticisms are subjective and only time will tell whether it is a durable machine.  I would get the non-ball version if I were to do it again, but then again, I don't do most of the vacuuming.

I started by purchasing the Dyson 33, which is aweful.  It will not get into the corners of your kitchen, but will have great suction in the general area of your home.  I returned it (didn't buy through Amazon).  Then I thought I wanted to try the DC24 and was immediately disappointed, returned it same day.  With regard to the Dyson 33, it has a great long cord that would reach into 3 rooms without unplugging and the 24 didn't get through one room.  Also, the attachments are very hard to work with as you have to pull the hose attachment out backwards, etc...just not a good buy.So I, still wanting a Dyson, decided to purchase the DC25, the animal version even though we have no animals.  Well, first off, the cord is longer, secondly, it gets great suction will get into corners and the attachments are easy to use. Love it.  I have both throw rugs and hard wood.  There is a button to press for each.  Don't waste your time with the 33 and the 24.  The only thing I would suggest to improve the Dyson 25 is to make the cord as long as the 33.  Then it would truly be a winner for those of us who do not like to vacuum!
