The cleaning wand, in our opinion is too long and makes it difficult to maneuver in tight corners and on stairs. 3.  The handle is not very comfortable when you have to vacuum for long periods of time.  It could use a different shape, or more rounded edges so it's not rubbing on your thumb.If the cleaning action stays as strong as promised, this will be the best vacuum I've ever owned.  Only time will tell.

We had bought a Dyson DC07 Full Gear four years ago, that machine still runs well today, but it was time to upgrade. So I did my research and decided on the DC25 Animal, after the the biggest reason we need a powerful vac is our Siberian Husky, those who know this dog know ful well that shedding season runs 365 days a year, how a single dog could shed SO much is beyond me. That being said, the Dyson is more than up to the task. Onto the new vac.......Pro's...New sleek design, improved tool design, more power with less noise (yes it's actually quieter) and the ball technology makes getting around so easy. Con's...they down sized the collection container, now it needs to be emptied a couple of times with the old one we could vac the whole upstairs and empty just once. They also shortened the electrical cord, not a major problem, but still something different. The quality of the build is mostly plastic, perhaps a concern, but the five year warranty gives peace of mind, I had never needed service with the old machine, I had some quetions and all were answered promptly and fully. All things considered I would buy this machine again.

column7: It SUCKS... and not in a good way
column8: Cable is too short. Telescope hose is too short. Attachments for the telescope are not mobile, so if you want to vacuum below your bed, the handle will get stuck.I prefer 100 times the old Dysons. After all the ball thing is not a big thing unless you have a round house.

this product is 100% worth every penny you spend on it, so don't feel bad.  i have had it for two days and my home literally feels brand new!  it picks up so much animal hair and dirt, it makes me sick to think about the filth i was living in.  also, the attachments are wonderful.  they are extremely practical and fit in all types of crevices, especially the staircase.  i even vacuumed under my bed and in all of the hard to reach corners.  the ball has tremendous flexibility and it doesn't weigh a lot so you don't have to strain yourself moving the machine back and forth.  i really have nothing negative to say about this product, so far.  i look at it as an investment (especially considering the 5 year warrany.)

column7: Not for hardwood floors (unless you want them scratched)
column8: Be aware that this vacuum cleaner has a major design flaw. It is designed to scratch hardwood floors by default because the brush turns on by default and there is no way to turn the vacuum on without the brush turning on automatically. It is only after the vacuum cleaner is switched on that you can press the button to turn the brush off. While this is happening the vacuum cleaner is scratching up the finish of the hardwood floor so over time you are going to see scratch marks created by the vacuum cleaner wherever you might have happened to turn the vacuum cleaner on. When I called to inquire if the brush operation is actually designed to scuff a finished hardwood floor each time the vacuum is turned on until I manually press the brush button to turn it off, I was told that that is in fact how the vacuum is designed. I was however offered the solution of placing the vacuum on a rug, turning it on and then manually turning the brush off, and then manually lifting and placing it on the finished hardwood floor. After spending $500, no thank you. This vacuum is going back where I bought it. I have to say though that the machine is very well made but due to the idiotic design of the brush switch, there is no way to turn the vacuum on without the brush turning on automatically. So this is a great vacuum cleaner if you have carpeted house but not suitable for homes with finished hardwood floors that would get scratched with the rotating brush. What a dissapointment!

I finally caved in and spent the money on the dyson DC25 animal ball.  I had been using a bissle vaccum for about a year as with any simple machine it had no suction for deep carpet and on tile would just blow the dust and hair around instead of picking up. Our carpets were matted down from foot traffic and looked cruddy because of the children spilling and dogs dragging everything around. I had read others reviews and specs on this dyson and decided to go ahead. I can not explain the improvment this vacuum has made on our home. within a 5x5 section I had to empty the can twice because of all the dust it had picked up it was very visable in the clear can what the old vacuum had failed to do. After cleaning the whole house over i could breathe the differance and see it on our entertainment center. The Dyson was very easy to assemble just attach a few parts out of the box and go. It was even more simple to find all the inner workings and trouble shooting paths with the instructions. its a simple advanced piece of equipment. the only downfall if the canister size its capacity is limited but not difficult to empty two simple buttons and your back in business. If your wanting a vaccum that does what its suppose to do drop the money and invest on a machine that will do its job.  You will notice the differance 100% the fist use and know that it will continue to work.
I was leary at first to spend the money for this vacuum.  Oh, am I glad I did.  It does everything and more that was promised.  Thanks Dyson

column7: The Dyson DC25 is absolutely amazing!!
column8: WOW.  I was totally amazed by this vacuum.  It has the strongest cleaning power I've ever used.  I have light ivory colored carpet and a black dog that sheds year round and lots of it.  My old vacuum could never seem to get quite all of the hair and the carpet didn't look much better after I was finished.  With the Dyson DC25 Animal Ball Upright Vacuum, my carpet looks brand new.  It's clean (the amount of dirt it picked up is phenomenal), and the whole house smells better because it's getting all the dog hair up out of the floor, and all the dirt that my other vacuum missed. Great Great product!!!!!

column7: Lives up to the hype so far
column8: I was tired of buying cheap vacuums that broke on me so I did some research on the best one to get. Almost every place I  check/person I asked came up with the same result - Dyson DC25.It's powerful, it's very easy to assemble, and every bit about it seems to be designed around usability. The ball lives up to the hype. The hose makes cleaning stairs a sinch. It goes from hardwood to rugs without slowing down. It handles corners well.It's great if you have allergies. You really can tell the difference.Since it's bagless I usually empty the canister outside. The canister detaches from the vacuum so I don't have to drag the entire thing around. I push a button to empty it outside and everything snaps back in easily.Is it expensive? Very much so. Am I wondering if I could have gotten the Hoover windtunnel instead to save a couple bucks? A little bit.Would I hesitate to buy this again if I did it all over? Not at all.

column7: Is not an improvement over DC17 Animal
column8: I was very excited in purchasing this vacuum cleaner. Previously I've owned a DC17 Animal since it's been on the market, and it still functions great! Due to some changes in our living arrangements etc. we do not have that vacuum cleaner in the house anymore. So we thought this would be a great chance to 'upgrade' to a newer version of Dyson. We've always wanted to try out the ball, seemed much easier to handle on the commercials, and we knew the technology and swore by it. Our original thought was to get the DC15 Ball, but for some reason that was 'sold out' or 'not in stock' at every store I looked at, including Amazon. After careful research we went with the DC 25 Animal.Well, in short, we were disappointed in this particular model (DC 25 Animal). Though the machine might be the best find for many, it did not measure up to our expectations from the DC17.Pros:- Light weight- Easy to maneuver- Easy to clean out the binCons:- Poor suction power (over the original DC17 Animal)- Short power cord- Small dust binOverall, I could not understand why this machine shares the 'Animal' with the DC17, aside from the color being common. It seems that Dyson took away the actual value of a vacuum cleaner and tremendously improved it's handling and weight. To me the most important thing for a vacuum cleaner is it's suction power and ease of cleaning. Though the ball makes it easy to 'roll around' the room, the plugging and unplugging adds a hassle that previously was not there.I could also understand if Dyson says that this vacuum cleaner was not meant to be as powerful as the DC17 (eg. 11amps vs. 12amps). Being the same color with a higher numbered model(DC25) and the same product label (Animal) gives the impression that it's a newer and better version to the old Animal. Nowhere in the ads did I see that this had less suction power than the DC17.I would recommend this vacuum cleaner to those who have only hardwood/tile floors or berber carpet and/or thin/silk rugs.I would NOT recommend this vacuum cleaner to those who have plush carpeting and/or big rooms.Detailed review:As a background here's our setting, and the environment we use the vacuum in:Our home  has hardwood and tile on the first floor, plush wall to wall carpeting on the second floor and stairs, and berber carpeting in our family room. Our pet is a medium hair cat.Weight: 5 out of 5 StarsA HUGE plus. This one probably weighs about half of DC17! Awesome improvement! I was able to pick this one up at any time, take it up or down the stairs without any problems.Handling: 4 out of 5 StarsA plus. It's definitely at least as easy as it's shown in the commercials.It's very easy to handle and maneuver around any furniture, chairs,  walls etc. The only thing I found awkward was the way you have to get the lever to 'click' on the bottom before it actually stays where you put it. Then you have to step on the lever a certain way to release and use the vacuum. The DC17 was easier this way, as soon as you brought it to the upright position it clicked and stayed. This one you have to make an additional effort for that special click.Capacity: 3 out of 5 StarsThe Clear Bin is very small. To me this is indifferent. I can make do, I'd just would have to empty the bin after each use. Though I'd prefer the machine be able to 'adjust' to my way of doing things, this is an easy enough change in my habits. It's easy enough to empty.Suction Power: 2 out of 5 StarsThis was one of the causes for me to return this model. After the price tag and the DC17 Animal (which is 12amps as opposed to 11amps on this one), this model did not seem to do a fair job on our wall to wall plush carpets in the bedrooms. However, it did do a great job on the hardwood, the rugs and the berber carpet. I could see it picking up the cat hair, just like the DC17.One 'improvement' to the DC17 is, it would do the rugs without lifting them and sucking them up. Doing the edges and corners of the rugs, it did not catch the corners and get stuck. With the DC17 we would have to have somebody hold down the edges/corners so the machine wouldn't grab it.On the stairs, the weight was very helpful, I could carry it up to the landing without a problem. However, the power of the new attachment is not even close to the one that was on the DC17. The DC17 actually CLEANED the carpet on the stairs, this one did not. You couldn't even see the 'vacuum mark' on the carpet. I was less than impressed.CORD Length: 1 out of 5 StarsThe cord is very very very short. With the DC17 I was able to plug it in, in the outlet right at the middle of the floor and was able to do the WHOLE floor without having to unplug and replug. This one, I barely was able to get halfway through the room before the cord ran out! Not sure what the reason of having a shorter cord would be. It's not user friendly at all.

column7: I Wreck Vacuums!  But Not This One/FREE replacement parts
column8: My history with vacuums is bleak. I wreck vacuums.  Bear with me while I tell the sad story with the happy ending.My first vacuum was a used truly ancient Hoover so old (but worked very well) it had the metal plate on the bottom that was easily removed with the flick of a turn style type large flat screw so the plate dropped off giving access to remove a jammed item or thread tangled around the roller or to change the belt.  Once belt changed, put plate on, turn large screw-Done. I wish I hadn't given it away.Since then I have owned 4 Hoovers.  With each constant 'what the hell is wrong with it now?', I would buy the next more expensive model hoping against hope that expense equaled RELIABILITY and EASE OF USE.  Alas it was not to be.  Over the years Hoover made it impossible to change a belt or remove a jam without using the tiniest of screwdrivers, spending hours taking the vacuum apart with dust flying everywhere and let's just say it is not surprising consumers are putting the local vacuum repairman's children though college.  There are vacuum repairs shops everywhere some quaintly called vacuum hospitals.  So there are 2 very expensive Hoovers in my garage with broken belts or some simple thing Hoover insists on making it impossible to easily remedy and the other 2 given away.  I am too cheap to give away the very expensive Hoovers and too stubborn to take them to a repair shop.  Between buying the Hoovers, I researched and purchased 2 Dirt Devils each more expensive than the other.  Like Hoovers, Dirt Devils are a pain in the rump to unjam and unlike Hoovers, they don't work as well.  I secretly wondered if vacuum manufacturers had stock in the repair shops.  So the Dirt Devils too sit in my garage.  I never purchased the cheapest vacuum model always mid-range up to the most expensive models.  Now understand, this vacuum accumulation is over 17 years and somewhere in there was the worst of vacuum of all - The Regina Housekeeper Plus which upon its maiden sweep, broke a belt or something. Off to vacuum hospital where the tech showed me a whole slew of Housekeepers, Hoovers, Dirt Devils, you name it lined up in his shop.  After the 3rd break in as many weeks and finding it impossible to find bags, The Housekeeper Plus was taken outside, smashed onto the sidewalk and dumped into the trash.  I used a broom and dust mop. (no carpeting in my house - tile and wood)With 2 older cats the broom method worked fine.  But in the last few years two stray kittens were adopted and the broom/dust mop method was no longer sufficient.  I spent HOURS researching vacuums/reading reviewer comments and no longer trusting Consumer Reports Magazine.  Spending hundreds of dollars on another crappy vacuum was NOT an option.  All I wanted was a vacuum that picked up cat hair/dander and dirt (as well as dog hair when my son and his dogs visited), was bagless ( I liked that in several of my Hoovers and one Dirt Devil) and something that little ole me could change a belt, unclog a jam and figure out what was wrong without a million tools or being rocket scientist.Answer: Dyson DC25 AnimalI jammed it within a week.  The handle would not go down.  Clenching my teeth, I saw a hose in the area where the handle refused to bend any longer. I easily unclasped the hose by squeezing the sides of the hose and out dropped a pen which wouldn't bend preventing the vacuum handle from going up.  NO BELTS that I can see and I have had mine for a year.  I ran over everything and everything was easily removed.  Several times the string on some cat toy or cord of a mini-blinds on my French door windows would wrap around the roller jamming it. Then came the real test.  While using the hose to vacuum around the cat bowls picking up stray hard cat food that spilled out of its bowl, the door bell rang.  Distracted, I accidentally ran the hose over a dish of wet Fancy Feast (Trout flavor) and the suction scooped some of it right up into the vacuum.  That gunked up the works and smelled like hell. Worse, the wet fishy Fancy Feast swirled around and mixed with the once dry Scoopable kitty litter that was vacuumed up around the cat box the day before. They call it CLUMPING for a reason. Having no time to clean it as I was called away, the Dyson was put away where the mess hardened and caked everywhere.  Surprisingly the vacuum still worked but the suction was down.  With much trepidation, Lysol cleaner, double rubber gloves, and most important of all a drywall sanding mask firmly in place, I went to work.  It was incredibly easy to remove the whole vacuum head, hoses, roller, and everything else because there was only a simple twist of one pair of plastic screws.  Dyson made access to every part EASILY reached and in no time the hose, roller, plastic roller casing (the underside of which was completely covered with gunk), etc. was sparkling clean.  I let it dry for a few hours, put it all back together in a snap and the vacuum works better than ever.I wreck vacuums.  But not a Dyson vacuum.Follow-Up June 2011 - I tore the hose reaching up CONSTANTLY to get the cobwebs in the corners of my EXTREMELY  high living room ceiling.  Once again, this was my fault, not the vacuum cleaner as I REALLY pulled the hose too many times and it finally gave.  I called Dyson to buy another hose and they said ONCE A YEAR you can call in and get one free part if a part breaks.  I received my 'free' hose last week.  Yet another reason to buy a Dyson.Follow-Up September - October - November 2012.  The hose is no longer reliable in suctioning. Sometimes it worked - sometimes it didn't.  I think it has to do with the foot pedal thing because if I lay the handle down and then lift it up a few times - sometimes the hose suction will return.  I was having eye issues so it was not a priority to call Dyson.  The brush floor part works great still.Follow-up January 2013  The brush stopped after I ran over a cell phone charger and the cord wrapped around the brush.  The vacuum stopped which it is supposed to do.  I unrolled the cord from the brush, hit red re-set button - nothing.  Hit the gray brush start button next to the red start button on handle - no luck.  Called Dyson.  My warranty runs out in 2013 and they are sending me a new brush area motor attachment (the whole area is one part for replacement.  Haven't received it yet - hope it fixes the brush problem.  At least the hose still works.Follow-up January 2013.  Hose does not work at all now.  I guess I wreck vacuums after all.  I cleaned the filter, I took the hoses off and checked for junk that may be stuck somewhere - nothing.FOLLOW -up January 2013 Dyson sent me another complete brush head (still under 5 year warranty) and I popped the old one off when I could see again after surgery (Blind from cataracts before) and the brush works now.  Hose suction still way down or way up - unreliable and Dyson authorized me to take the vacuum to a repair shop.  I think it has something to do with how the handle goes up and down.  I found a clear plastic piece after my eye surgery that 'might' below to the vacuum bottom.  I'll take it with me when dropping off the vacuum.

column7: I can see why there is all the hype!
column8: After much deliberation I finally broke down and decided to get the Dyson DC25 Animal. I relied on many reviews here and other places in making my purchase so I felt the need to contribute back with my review. I paid a little over $400 at another retailer (after discounts) and I feel it is well worth the money. The suction is definitely the strongest I have experienced in a vacuum. This is my first higher end vacuum so I was impressed by many of the features. The swivel ball is nice, definitely a step up over the regular one way vacuums. I would recommend this to most people who are fed up with the cheap vacuums like I once was.

This is my sixth vacuum and by far the best!  I cannot believe how much suction this little machine has. On first day of use, it was actually shocking to learn my carpets were that dirty!  This vacuum is light weight very easy to use.  We have 3 girls with very long hair, a cat and a dog.  My kids can carry the vacuum up and down the stairs without problem.  The best feature that I like is I don't have to worry about any belts breaking or falling off continuously like all my previous vacuums. The Dyson ball has a separate motor with no belts!  I also like how the vacuum is designed to reach under furniture and swivel into corners. It's small and doesn't take up much space and fits in my coat closet perfectly.  Not having to buy bags and filters is also a plus.

Update from my last review...  I've had my Dyson for two years now.  It is still doing a stellar job.  I have a husky that is an unbelievable shedder, and this vacuum sucks up his hair like no other I've owned.  No regrets with this purchase!!!  Expensive, but worth it.

Over the years my husband and I have owned a number of vacuums. We have had the DC25 Animal since July 2009. We have always had animals, and currently own 3 heavy-coated dogs. They have a long over-coat and wooly under coat, both constantly shedding fur.This vacuum, as my husband puts it, kicks 7 levels of butt. It really does a brilliant job cleaning the carpets from the tons of dog fur. In addition, the design of the brush with its easy removal and easy cleaning is the best design ever. Our last vacuum(Hoover bagless) died from repeatly requiring that the brush assembly be taken apart to clean it of long fur. It was an absolutely agonizing task to clean the brushes. Not so the dyson, it is really easy - a brilliant design. This has been the best vacuum I have ever used - no doubt. Excellent design, fairly light, moves easiy, and doesn't make that gross 'vacuum smell'.Love it!!!!!!!!
Overall I am very pleased with the Dyson.  It has great suction, is lightweight, and you can maneuver great with the Dyson Ball technology.  You can see my full pro and con list here ... [...]

We jumped on the Dyson train 4 years ago with the Dyson animal. Yes, it can suck dirt you never knew existed in your carpet but what we have learned over several years of use is that this beautiful piece of purple engineering is flawed in many ways. First, the hose was replaced twice for cracking. Always at our expense. Keep in mind that we aren't using the thing commercially, just your average once a week cleaning. Then the clear plastic handle that you carry the heavy unit by when going upstairs cracked and finally broke completely off. Sadly that wasn't even the worst part. Shortly after that broke, the thin PLASTIC piece that holds the handle to the unit which you use to release the wand broke off making vacuuming with this extremely expensive machine virtually impossible. Of course all of this happened just past the warranty date.For such a well designed vacuum, Dyson could have done a much better job engineering the parts of the machine that you kind of take for granted like the handles. I had a $75 bag vacuum that lasted for 12 years and actually was still going strong but have two big dogs and thought the Animal was needed. I would have expected a $550 machine to last longer than 5.5 years.Buy at your own risk.

[Reviewer profile]-full time house maker-have a heavy-shedding-breed dog-vacuum every day-went through gametes of vacuum machines-use several different kinds of method to cleanI purchased Dyson DC25 Animal during the week of Christmas 2009.On the very first day, I was shocked and amazed of how dirty my home was; I had to empty three times just to vacuum the living room. It seemed as though I never vacuumed my place.I saw more minute dust particles colored sandy white compared to other vacuumed dusts.Ever since then, vacuuming became one of my favorite activities of a day.1. Quality of vacuum  ; I usually take a couple of steps when I vacuum - Pet hair remover & brush, vacuum, wet-cloth wiping, vacuum.  With Dyson DC 25, I can skip front two steps and get the same result which often takes a half amount of time to do the same job.  Dyson DC25 does not give off the typical dusty smell of vacuuming.  If I do, the filter must be cleaned or emptied.  As long as I follow the recommended maintenance process, it works consistently and strongly.2. Handling  ; Enough weight to hold down the vacuum without flipping accidents or feeling that I'm just grazing the floor or carpet.3. Maintenance  ; Surprisingly easy and quick from emptying the canister to washing filter.

This vacuum is the most awesome thing ever!  My husband won't even let me use it, he had cleaned every room in the house and we have only had it since Christmas!I have sold the idea of the ball to many of my coworkers.

I wanted to love this.  I loved the ball, the maneuverability.  I ended up returning it, but only because it didn't pick up well on my kitchen floor.  All it did, was push around cheerios, chips, or whatever other food my kids dropped.  It sucked up dust, etc very well.  But any food particles, it would just not suck up.  I tried it a few times, cuz I really wanted it to work.  At one point I thought it picked up everything, then I turned it off and went to move the vacuum and everything fell out the bottom. It picked up on the carpet fine.  I'm not sure it was any better than any other vacuum though.Overall I guess if you just have carpet and want the maneuverability then this is a good investment.  I loved the ball concept.  Just wish it picked up better.

I bought this very dyson (DC25 Animal Ball) about 2 years ago specifically because my hair sheds like mad. My sister (who has the same problem) bought the dyson animal about 5 years ago. LOVES it still. When I saw the price tag, initall, I couldn't fathom spending that kind of money for a vacuum cleaner. But I kept reading reviews on line & my sis & friends all swore by it so I bit the bullet and bought the animal/ball.  BEST PURCHASE I ever made!! You don't realize how much dust is in your house until you use the dyson. I always thought my floors were clean (mind you we don't wear shoes indoors). The Dyson is worth every penny. The suction CLEANS EVERYTHING! And the ball technology isn't hype. It fantastic. Vacuuming around tables,chairs, corners ... soooo easy to do. The wand makes cleaning ceiling corners and base boards so easy.  My only regret is not buying it sooner. Even if you hate vacuuming, you'll love the dyson.

column7: The best vacuum cleaner I've ever used
column8: My Bissell upright canister vacuum cleaner recently broke.  Before I go out and buy another one, I spent several weeks researching and finally settled on Dyson DC25 Animal.  I bought it based on the numerous positive review from customers who has one, and because of the great warranty that comes with it.  I also like DC25 design.  It's light enough for my wife and I to move it up and down between first and third floor of our home.  The additional motorized brush can be used to clean car seats and carpet and it did not add that much more to the cost of the original DC25.  The vacuum cleaner arrived yesterday.  My 4 year old daughter and I unpacked the box and put it together.  First thing I noticed after turning it on for the first time was that the noise level, unlike that of my old Bissell, was not so loud as to scare off my daughter like the Bissell did.  Secondly, vacuuming from rug to hardwood floor to thick padding carpet felt smooth, light, and easily maneuverable around furnitures.  It was so easy that my 4 year old, who wanted to be so helpful, was able to vacuum most of our bedroom on her own without any assistance from me.  Another thing that I noticed that when I had the DC25 up against the wall, it actually pick up the dust on the edge of the wall.  My old Bissell that supposedly had a built in 'edge to edge technology' couldn't do that even when it was brand new.  We always had to go over the edge along the wall using the attachment.  I was surprised how much dust and what not that it pulled.  I had to empty out the canister after vacuuming couple of bedrooms.  It goes to show just how little our old Bissell cleaned.  I am thoroughly impressed with the DC25 animal.  $599 is a steep price tag for a vacuum cleaner.  If you search around like I did, you can find it for less.  I got it for $469 with free shipping.  I got it a week after I ordered it.

I purchased one yesterday and was very excited to try it out.  It was so cool looking and easy to manuver.  I eagerly turned on the machine and made a few easy strokes..... huh? Something must be wrong.  It didn't even erase the footprints in the carpet and the suction was ok at best.  I switched off the brush bar and looked in the end, nothing was wrong.  I called customer service and after about 15 minutes on the phone with them figured out it was working properly. What the heck?I expected this thing to suck so hard that it would lift the carpet and create perfecty groomed rows of nap...like a freshly plowed field.  Not even close it barely even combed the top of the fibers.Problem #1-No height adjustment for the brush bar.  It barely even touches the carpet.  Not enough to even give you that 'just vacuumed' look.  Talk about a suction leak.Problem #2-It doesn't have very good sucking power.  My old Bissel sucked 2x as hard as this dyson.  Even the guy on the customer care line said it only moved about 50CFM of air compared to my old vacuum that moved much much more.Don't belive the marketing hype.  It's not worth the money.  Ever wonder why consumer reports ranks the cleaning ability of the Dyson as average?  Because it is.  Consumer reports is dead on in their review.  It's just not that good of a cleaner.Sure it looks cool and you can park it in the driveway to impress your neighbors... but as far as cleaning my carpets, this vacuum sucks - Not in a good way.I took it back to the store a few hours later and got my money back.  If I want a vacuum that cleans just OK then I'm not going to pay [...] bucks.  The 99 dollar ones at Target work just as good, if not better.

Have owned this product for three months.  I never liked to vacuum, but now it is a pleasure.  The ball technology is amazing and it handles like a fine sports car.  We have a large german shepard who sheds a lot. I vacuumed with our old cleaner and then went over the same surface with the Dyson.  I could not believe how much fur it picked up.  I highly recomend this prodcut.

column7: Excellent vacuum cleaner, works like a charm
column8: We just bought this yesterday at the Kohls Black Friday deal, and, after all the discounts, and cash backs, cost us less than half its original price, so it was a great deal! We cleaned our carpet after our Bissell and Hoover vacuums broke down, and the amount of dirt it picked up was phenomenal! It cleaned the hard wood really well too, and after the Hoover Windtunnel, in which we had to switch the cleaning from carpet to harwood everytime, this was a piece of cake. The only drawbacks were the frequency with which we had to empty the trash container and the shortness of the cord, we had to physically plug it in each room. The Bissell and Hoover worked in at least 2 rooms without unplugging. Just to vacuum our 1000 sq ft first floor, we had to empty the trash bin thrice. The instructions to open the box were on the top of the box itself, and the installation process is 1-2-3, snap, easy. I'm not a very mechanical person, but I had the vacuum cleaner ready in 5 minutes, with the help of my 7 year old. It's also quieter than my other vacuum cleaners, my 5 year old son fell asleep with the vacuum on. Also, it has good maneuverability, better than my other vacuum cleaners, and its lighter. All in all, am very happy with this!

Just purchased the Dyson DC25 Animal machine.  All I can say is WOW.  Unbelievably easy to put together.  Literally 3 things to 'snap' into place.  It took me longer to get everything out of the box.  I immediately thought 'Oh oh, something this easy is going to have problems.' None at all.To give it the real life test, I had just changed the belt on my Bissell Velocity All-Floor (BTW - This was an OK machine and probably a good value for the price, but I kept getting tired of it falling over every time I used the hand attachments and moved more than 2 feet away from the machine.  READ ON), emptied the bin,  then  vacuumed the living room floor.  Typical job.  Then I re-vacuumed the same area with the Dyson.  I expected a small amount in the bin, but got much more.  As I said, I believe the Bissell to be a very solid machine, but the Dyson just way outperforms.WOW!
I was concerned when I saw the plastic like parts to snap together, but the vacuum works beautifully and is very lightweight.

Product was lost through Fed ex!!!  Until Fed ex admitted total lost could Amazon send replacement.  Amazon did replace it 7 days to my door  ...(total 41 days to my door).  As for the Dyson DC25 animal.... It drives like an italian sports car and sucks like a ***** in heat and absolutely no exhaust filth. I love this expensive product.

column7: Great Design but the cord is too short
column8: We purchased the Dyson Animal 25 about six weeks ago and the ball design is fantastic.  It truly makes vacuuming easy enough that our kids want to do it. (total bonus) It maintains suction as advertised and does really well at getting suction to baseboards and in corners.  Overall this is a greaty vacuum and worth the price but the one major issue that they need to address is the cord length.  It needs to be about 15 feet longer.  I realize that they were trying to keep weight to a minimum but how much does another 15 feet of cord weigh?

I traded in a cheaper Dirt Devil vac for the Dyson DC25 and I couldn't be happier.  Yes, it was more money but you get what you pay for and I paid for clean rugs that look new- despite them being 12 years old!  I have two cats and three levels of carpets that look fabulous!  I agree with those that said it was annoying to have to empty the bin- but it was easy enough so the annoyance level in my opinion was minimal.I did a lot of research before selecting this vacuum and I'm not sorry for what I paid for it.  I would've done it sooner if I knew my carpets would look as fantastic as they do now.So if you can afford it- buy this vacuum. Your carpets will thank you.

Please do not waste your money on the name of this product! Just because some handsome foreigner comes on your television screen to tell you how dramatically engineered this machine is, that is no reason to be swept up (which the product does not do) and sucked into (the vacuum doesn't do that either) his salesmanship.I bought the DC 25 in January, 2009.  By March, 2009, I was ready to have the blasted thing carted away from my home by the garbage men.  The only thing that kept it from the dump was that my college-age son had no vacuum at all and appreciated a machine that would at least pick up his roommate's sandwich scraps.My housekeeper was the first to let me know what a cheap piece of machinery this was.  She liked the way it crept around corners, but she did not like its LACK OF SUCTION.  She said she had to go over spaces on the floor several more time than she had to with my Hoover that she used previously on her visits.  I vacuumed the carpet twice, perhaps four times, between her twice monthly visits.  With the Dyson, she noticed a remarkable lack of care.One thing I noticed was the lack of ability to 'fluff' my carpet back up.  My Hoover used to make my carpets look all new and fresh.  The Dyson keeps my carpet looking beat down and dirty.  Especially since I have pets, this is an important thing for me.  I do not want to feel like I need to replace my carpeting before it is time to do so.  My carpeting has a 15 year limited warranty. It has barely been nine years, and since I have been using the Dyson for the last 9 months, it looks terribly worse.  Also, I find the fact that it does not have 'headlights' a discouraging point.  I have to turn every lamp and light on in every room to see what I am doing while I vacuum with the Dyson. They are cheap in this matter.I know this review is getting very long, but there is one more important factor I must share with you.I have a home carpet cleaner.  It is also a Hoover product.  I try to clean each carpeted room on a regular basis.  Since I have purchased the Dyson, I find that my carpet cleaner is filled with much more dog hair and soot than it used to have.  This tells me the Dyson vacuum is not picking up the dirt it claims to.Don't waste your money.  Go back to what you trust for half the price.
This vacuum is fantastic!  It it is a bit expensive but, it's worth it.  The attached hose thing is a bit tricky at first but, you'll get used to it.

I have never owned a 'luxury' vacuum before. I had been coveting the Dyson for a long time. This one seems to be made for me.I had recently had new carpets installed, and my old vaccum was not up to the task. The rugs kept shedding and shedding because the vacuum just wasn't picking up the excess yarn.The first time I used my Dyson DC25 Animal, I had to empty the canister literally every room (and I had vacuumed using an inexpensive Hoover vacuum about three days earlier). There were entire cats in that canister. It is so oddly satisfying SEEING the junk in your carpet in a clear canister rather than having it all hidden away in a bag, where one can only wonder what disgustingness might have lurked.So, yeah, it took care of the cat hair and the shedding carpet. And it's lightweight and very manueverable: the ball means that you can turn it any which way you want while you're pushing this thing around. It's a very neat feature.Then comes the coolest part for me: it's certified asthma-friendly by the Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America. I'm lucky enough to be blessed with both asthma and allergies, and vacuuming has been a particular nightmare this allergy season. It has always seemed that my vacuums kicked up more stuff than they took care of. Not so with the Dyson, which has a lifetime HEPA filer that traps allergens.The wand attachment is built right into the handle-- you just open a cap on top and the wand extends out from there. Very simple.There are no bags to worry about, and it's easy to empty and put back together. The handle is ergonomic, and there's no need to change settings when switching from bare floors to carpet. The machine just knows.Also, it's freakin' purple.There are three details I'd love to see improved: 1. a larger canister, 2. a little more room to maneuver the wand-- it's kind of awkward as is, and 3. a retractable cord. All corded things in life should have retractable cords. Cords are very cordy.Even soulmates, however, are not expected to be perfect. My love for my Dyson is unconditional and everlasting. I (heart) U, DC25 Animal.

I bought this vacuum from Amazon a couple of months ago.  Not only did I recieve it promptly, but I love it.  It's is the best vacuum I've owned to date. I was a little leary of it not being self propelled, but this is actually easier to use than self propelled models I've previously owned.  The ball technology does exactly what it implies.  I have an indoor dog who sheds a considerable amount, and the Dyson really sucks up the hair! I even steam cleaned my carpet after vacuuming with the Dyson & there was almost no dirt in the recovery tank. It works really well on my hardwood floors too & the hand tools are easy to use for cleaning the couch and other things.  I would definitely recommend this vacuum!

After much research, I just bought this vacuum, and it's fantastic.  Can't believe how much dog hair and dirt was hiding in my carpet.  Relatively small bin filled up fast because of all the dog hair, but very easy to empty, so not a problem.  In fact it was satisfying to see how much the vac was collecting and also to know I won't have to be buying new bags all the time.Easy to assemble; hardest part was getting it out of the box because I didn't see the 'how to open' directions -- but they're there!  Don't overlook the mini turbine attachment in the box.

Not good for a house with birds e.g., parakeets and parrots.  The downy like feathers tend to clog the system.  Also, the individual suction devices need to be cleaned over time as they tend to clog with debris.  This can be tricky.  Don't really see any discernable differences between high end and low end priced models other than certain features.  The basic unit is the same.

I've owned a lot of vacuums. In the recent past, a number of Hoover Wind Tunnels, in part due to the rave reviews on Consumer Reports and I liked their embedded dust finder. Consumers was never very hot on Dyson, but recently I found that Consumer Reports has some serious problems with Vacuum reviews and they are flat out wrong about Dyson. Anyway, after 4 years, my last Hoover bite the dust, I was tired of spending $100 every few years getting it repaired and decided that I would not follow their advise but rather come here to Amazon and see what real users say about various products. First of all, the Dyson reviews as anyone can see are stellar. Next, reading about Hoover Wind Tunnels as well, it seems my experience with them matched others; great the first year, then down hill from there on with lots of repairs. Still, $550 for a Vac, that's crazy. Or is it? Well with a 5 warranty, great reviews and some long saved Amazon points from my credit card use, I decided to go with the DC25 Animal. I only wish I had purchased sooner. As others have said, the out of box experience was excellent. Easy to setup. No masses of non recyclable Styrofoam. A nice looking manual with an actual registration card where one can find the serial number. Great web site. So far, so good.First 20 minutes of trying it out, I was in love. Didn't find the ball difficult to get the hang of, just the opposite. Love the ability to turn the beater brush on and off from the handle, unlike the Hoover that was down by the floor and difficult to engage due to the cheap plastic. The DC25 is very light, not noisy. But the amazing part was seeing the basket fill with dog hair and gunk quickly, even though I had used the hoover only a few days before. This Vac sucks like there's no tomorrow! I was shocked by the amount of dirt it picked up. The carpets looked excellent and of course, the DC25 has no problems keeping my tile clean. I like how the unit lifts its back wheels when you engage the unit to vac. So the downside? Well as some have said here, the cord isn't all that long. But heck, even at twice its size, it wouldn't be long enough if the goal is to vac an entire home of a decent size without moving to another outlet. And here are two words to take care of the cord issue: Extension Cord. Sure, it works with a 50 foot extension which can be rolled up with a nice clip and hung over the handle. That problem was solved. I also appreciate that unlike the Hoover, the cord wasn't black but a light gray. My walls are all white and I can't tell you how often the damn Hoover cord would scuff them up with a black marking as you pull it by the walls. I can't say for sure this will not happen with the Dyson but I doubt it (the orange extension cord mentioned above that I used with the Hoover never scuffed the walls).Now onto the small dirt basket. Yes its smaller than other Dysons. But if you find it fills quickly (like I did on the first use), well guess what? You have a dirty home <g>. Just kidding. I did have to empty it half way through the first vacuuming but I suspect as all that old, accumulated dirt my Hoover didn't get is taken care of, this will be less an issue. And emptying is super quick and easy. Its also nice not having to deal with bags. Consumers wasn't all that hot on bagless vac's but after decades of using them, I think I'll be far happier dumping this gung out every time and seeing what I'm picking up as I vacuum. Will save me a ton of money too. Those good Hoover bags are expensive and add up.So my only minor complaint is that while I spent the extra $$ for the Animal attachment (as others have said, that's the only difference other than color between these two Ball units), it doesn't appear to attache to the body of the DC25 like the other tools. That said, it works quite well. We have three dogs, one a Husky that sheds a ton. She likes to get up on leather couch so we keep a pad there. This attachment sucked up the hair beautifully meaning that it will get popped into the washing machine a bit less, saving more money and water. See, you really can justify a $550 Vac if you wan to.Seriously, this really is a lot of money for a vacuum. Unless Dyson has some magical drug embedded into the handle, its pretty clear they can get away with this price because the damn thing is a superb product. The number of reviews here convinced me with only a reservation on the cost but I can honestly say, it was worth every penny, at least so far. If it is reliable unlike my Hoover, I'll be a very happy and life long Dyson customer.

My wife and I have been married for 10 years.  In that time, we've been owners of four of Comsumer Reports' 'best buy' vacuums.  None of them work today.  Upon the last one bellowing smoke, I decided that I'd check out the ratings again.  The Dyson was NOT highly rated, and very expensive.  I decided to go with the Kenmore 'Progressive' bagless.  When I got to Sears to buy my $300 vacuum, it looked and felt so cheap, that I couldn't make myself do it.I walked over to the shelf where the Dyson's were.  Talk about well made!  That was enough to get me to try it.  $467 later (Sears was running a 15% off sale), I'm the proud owner of a DC-25 Animal.This thing is amazing.  Although I'm not the primary 'vacuumer' of the house, I had to try this thing out.  Our bedroom is 15' X 18'.  After vacuuming this room, I had half of a bathroom trash can full of dog hair and dirt that we could never see!  This is after borrowing my neighbor's new Hoover that she swears by.The only thing that I would change:  Larger capacity.  I had to empty this thing several times just to do one room.  I don't think we'll have that problem in the future, now that the carpet has been 'Dyson'd'.Summary:  This thing is worth the $$.  After years of my wife complaining about different vacuum cleaners, she absolutely loves this one.  This machine is very easy to assemble out of the box.  The assembly instructions have no pictures, and is only three sentences long.  If you're looking for a good vacuum cleaner with a 5 year warranty, spend the $$, you won't have to buy 2 or 3 more in the next decade.

DC25 Animal, only thing to improve is to make it lay flat and go under furniture.  Other than that this thing sucked up over 3/4  lbs of dirt and animal hair off of just one of my rugs after I had vacuumed it with my regular vacuum cleaner for a test.  I would definately recommend this to anyone who can afford it.  I was to cheap to buy one and my dear loving husband bought it while I was on vacation and surprised me on my return.  My immediate thought was to return it and get the money back but after the one use I will never part with it. 5 stars all the way.  Some people complain about the cord being to short and the bin being to small, it is worth it if I have empty every 10 minutes, this thing is awesome.V/rRedneck Wife.
Excellent product, very pleased with the vendor purchased fromcame in a timely manner....

I've used the DC25 Animal for a couple of weeks now. Before purchasing, I read the reviews here, the negative ones especially carefully.Regarding the broken belt reports, those just have to be false. There are no belts in this design; the beater bar is direct-drive and conveniently switchable.The integrated handle and extension wand do seem odd at first, but they really become very easy to use after doing it a time or two. The hose is stiff, but it works and has a good reach.While the collection bin does seem on the small side, we have found that the hair and debris becomes very compressed at the bottom of the bin, so we really don't need to dump the bin any more often than with previous vacuums.And giving the collection bin a couple of shakes before opening the bottom cover usually dislodges the compressed pet hair in our experience. A time or two I've had to release a hair clump by hand, which is no big deal.One reviewer said the attachments fall off of the unit while vacuuming. On my DC25, they attach to their storage and usage positions with a positive 'snap,' and stay snug and secure at all times. If attachments fall off, make sure they are inserted properly so that they snap into place.I agree that the power cord is too short; it takes three outlets to do each level of our two-story house.We have found the hand-held head (with suction-powered beater bars) extremely effective. It is not at all difficult to angle the head properly for maximum suction; I do the carpeted stairs much more rapidly -- and effectively -- with this attachment. Just remember where you put it; there is no onboard storage for this particular tool.Those who have trouble cleaning certain surfaces with the hand-held beater bar attachment should try a variety of techniques. For example, I cleaned a fabric suitcase covered with pet hair by using a side-to-side motion, instead of front-to-back. Our mattress and cloth car seats responded best to a circular motion. Using this attachment requires a little experimentation, which is quick and easy. Just try different patterns until the crud starts coming off.I particularly like the maneuverability of the ball design. It takes a minute or two to get used to, but it becomes very easy to maneuver, and reduces cleaning time.The DC25 Animal picks up a lot more dirt, and somewhat more pet hair, than our previous vacuums. One of these was an Amway Cleartrack, the design of which was, IIRC, 'borrowed' by the corporation from an earlier Dyson design, until Dyson prevailed in a lawsuit. We also used a couple of Hoover models.The DC25's plastic design seems sturdy enough, but only time will tell how durable the unit will be.It requires a little force to return the unit to its upright position, but you can lessen the force required by 'helping' the wheels drop via some gentle pressure with your foot. Even without doing this, though, my wife and I have no difficulty returning the DC25 Animal to the upright position.The unit is very light and is a beautiful piece of engineering. All seals tighten up snugly during operation, and the suction is very strong. The switchable electric beater bar is excllent, and this unit handles transitions from hard surfaces to carpeted surfaces better than any vaccuum I have used over the past 30 years.The unit is well balanced for carrying when using the collection bin handle as recommended.Other bagless vacs we have used have allowed a lot of dust and pet hair to make it through to the pre-motor filter(s). Not so with this unit. After many hours of use, only a small amount of very fine dust has collected on the washable cloth pre-motor filter. Dyson recommends rinsing this and the exhaust filter every few months.This unit also draws a couple less amps during operation than our previous vac, as measured with a Kill-a-Watt.All in all, I would say that the DC25 Animal is worth the price. It is a beautiful machine from both an engineering and aesthetic standpoint, but -- more importantly -- it does an exceptional job of cleaning multiple surfaces.

It is better than any other vacuum cleaner I've tried. However, it still has some flaws, that I would like to mention.It really vacuums much better than the previous cleaners I've had, it's light, easy to operate, easy to clean, no neccessary filters to buy, just wash filters every three months.Overall, very good vacuum. And that ball is awesome. Very maneuverable.Cons:1. The outlet plug unplugs very easy, it doesn't stay plugged while vacuuming. Minor annoyance.2. The Quick-draw Telescope Reach wand is very unpractical to work with. Maybe it was meant for high to reach places, but not for stairs. It's not flexible.I purchased it at BedBathAndBeyond with a 20% Off coupon and very glad I did.

We bought this vacuum this weekend to replace a long-owned and much-abused model by a different brand. Not only is this vacuum impressively more powerful than any previous one I've used, but it's also much simpler to drive around furniture. It makes vacuuming fun.The attachments are great for stairs, getting pet hair off of couches, hard to reach places, everything. I think my favorite thing about this vacuum is how effortless it makes cleaning - if you need the wand, you just pull and you're ready to go. It's so light that it makes multi-floor vacuuming simple and painless.Try it!

column7: Never thought I'd be in love with a vacuum...
column8: ...but stranger things have happened!I had wanted a Dyson for some time, so after much procrastination, I finally got one.As pretty much all previous positive reviewers have said, this vacuum really does work great. The suction is fantastic. The tools are easy to use, though the hose does take some getting used to, but that's pretty minor. It's a good size and weight, not too heavy. I find it's not exactly quiet, but not roaring like a jet engine either. After vacuuming my entire house with the Dyson, I can walk around in bare feet and I feel absolutely no dirt or debris whatsoever on the floor. It's SUPER clean! It's amazing.Others have said emptying it gives off a puff of dust a bit, and that's true, but it's a trade-off from not having to buy bags! The Dyson seems to compact the dust and sand-like dirt down to the bottom of the canister though, so when you hit the trap door, it falls out first. The cord is another thing people have touched on. Yes, it's shorter than some vacuums, but that's another trade-off to having a lighter machine. Slightly smaller bin size was another one, but that's also not a very big deal to me.I've read all of the reviews on this model on every conceivable website. The negative reviews I found seemed to be mainly from people who 1)unfortunately got the 1 lemon out of a bajillion Dysons, which seems rare. 2)will never be satisfied no matter what. 3)have some sort of bizarre reverse snobbery aversion to Dyson's products. Or 4)have concerns that to me are just personal pet peeves like the cord length, bin size, etc.The overwhelming majority of people who bought the Dyson Ball either love it or like it a whole lot, so take those negative reviews with a grain of salt. I personally love using this vacuum and will no longer slack on the vacuuming!

Only had the Dyson a few weeks but it's great.  It cleaned stuff out of our carpet that must have been there forever. I can't imagine that there was that much dog hair in our carptet that our centrl vacuum missed.The Dyson is pricy but well worth it if you want something that really cleans.

Outstanding vacuum, very well designed and thought-out.  Points previously discussed:1)  Yes, it's plastic.  Probably why it weighs only 16 lbs, and seems to be pretty tough stuff; I vote light weight rather than cast-iron.  Our Hoover weighed in at 24 lbs and was literally two dozen pounds of junk;  probably would have made a good boat anchor (and do a better job than it ever did as a vacuum).  We'll see how durable it is, but so far, pretty impressed.2)  The cord is 24 feet long; that's about all I'm willing to try and wrap around my arm while vacuuming, and is plenty long for any room in our house.3)  Tremendous vacuum power; emptying canister is not an issue - yes, it fills up with stuff, like all other bagless HEPA canisters I've ever seen or tried.  If you don't want to look at dust, empty dust, or see dust fall out into your wastebasket, get a bag vacuum.  Emptying, by the way, involves pressing two buttons - one to get the canister off the vacuum, and one to dump from the bottom of the canister directly into the trash.  Sweet.4)  More agile than any vacuum we've ever tried - the smaller head really gets into places other vacuums couldn't reach, and the ball is a breeze to maneuver.  Yes, the ball is too large to get under some furniture, but the vacuum head reaches as far as our ex-Hoover, and the detachable hose is really slick to use if you need to get all the way under, say, a bed.A bargain even at the high(er) price.  You only pay once for quality.

column7: I'll never buy a cheap vacuum again!
column8: The price always held me back from purchasing a Dyson. But owning multiple pets meant replacing my cheap vacuums annually, and with matching cheap warranties, I never felt like I was getting a 'bargain'.So I pried the money out of savings and bought the Animal. I love this vacuum!Pros: My wood floors have never been cleaner Our family dust allergies have been greatly reduced Regular use is reducing the amount of furniture dusting I have to do The 'Animal' attachment is well-designed and effective (unlike the cheaper versions I've tried) The beater actually TURNS OFF when you're doing hard floors Five year warrantyCons: The price may be prohibitive for some The cord is a little short (but I can do most of 1800 sq ft with 1 move) The ball is challenging when one is used to a standard vacuum The ball is rather tall - and prevents getting underneath lower furniture without using the wandRecommendation: If your home has shedding pets, this IS the vacuum for you!

I purchased this vacuum about two weeks ago and a few days ago I was finally able to put it together with the free time I had. I was curious how well it stood up against my old trusty hoover (it was definitely coming of age and needed replacing). I have a one-bedroom apartment and after the hoover was finished I turned to the Dyson and it was amazing how much more this vacuum picked up. Now I had to empty the container about 3 times and not because of the size of the container but the amount of pet hair it picked up compared to the old vacuum.As for price of this vacuum, you definitely should carefully weight it in to your decision making. I justified it because of my two cats, but if you just want the power then definitely take your time and do some more research.In the end this was definitely the vacuum for me.

I love this vacuum. I've always been skeptical of the vacuums that um...cost more than $50...that's all I've ever had and I thought they worked fine. Well I was wrong.  I bought the DC 25 animal with money we received for our wedding and holy crap.  I'm in love. We have a cat that somehow generates a sort of cat hair tumbleweed that up to this point would just run away from brooms and vacuums.  But this vacuum really sucks!!!  Somehow it doesn't let the tumbleweeds escape.  Oh, and the fuzz was the worst on hard floors, which I've never been able to effectively vacuum with the cheap-o vacuums that I've had before, and the promise is true, this thing works on all types of floors!Bottom Line.--Things I love:+Suction power -- WOW!+Maneuverability of ball+Attachments for the handle (I can just leave the vacuum on and get the cobwebs from the ceiling while I'm there -- no more 'Webster')+Super quiet (no motor sound, just like a sucking sound -- I don't know how to explain it)+On the trash canister, the release button to open the bottom is right at the top, nowhere near where the actual dirt comes out.+Spinning carpet brush comes out super easily to clean separate of the vacuum so you don't have to get down on your hands and knees and disgustingly yank out hairs or strings that've gotten stuck.+Stores really easily in our small coat closet by the front door.--Things I don't love:+Price!  Yes, its a lot of money, but if you have the money or just come across it luckily (like we did), its worth it.

After upgrading from our 3 yr. old Dyson to this model, we are very pleased.  The only downfall would be the smaller canister/dust container.  The exercise to the trash is much welcomed due the appreciation we have for this machine.  We have 3 large long hair dogs and it cleans our carpets wonderfully.  As allergy sufferers, after vacuuming, the sneezes and runny noses seize.  The ball makes it very easy to manuever around furniture and for a 'vacuumee' who is disabled, this vacuum is the easiest and best worker and very well worth the extra money. We tried it out at Best Buy first for a 'test drive'.  This is definitely a good idea if you aren't sure about spending over $300.00 on a vacuum.  Even the sales personnel there said they've had little to no returns on the Dysons as compared to the other brands that attempt to mimic their brand.

This is absolutely the best vacuum cleaner I have ever owned. I have two cats and a dog who all shed quite a bit. Previous vacuums picked up the dirt, but only partially removed the animal hairs. My Dyson does a wonderful job and makes my carpets look like new. I've had this vacuum cleaner for several years now and I have never had one problem with it. Dyson came out with a newer model, but this one works like a charm, so I won't buy a new one yet. But when time comes for buying a new vacuum cleaner, it will definitely be another Dyson Animal.

I don't love vacuuming but with this machine - I don't hate it anymore.  We have a two story home and two dogs and after struggling with a cheaper vacuum, it was heaven to use this Dyson.  I've had a Dyson in the past and wasn't impressed, so it took a lot for me to go back to the brand but I am glad that I did.  I find that the ball technology makes maneuvering the machine easy and although others complain about the reduced size of the collection chamber, it is not so small that I would chose a model without the ball.

I bought this to replace an aging Kirby vacuum. When I vacuumed a room that I had just finished with the kirby I had to empty the canister twice. It has the best suction I have ever seen in a vacuum.If I have one criticism it is the hose for the hand tools. It is way too stiff and you have to hold the vac with one hand while you use the hand tools or you will pull the vacuum over.

I borrowed my friend's DC25 and LOVED it. I don't get excited about ANY kind of housework but this thing cut my vacuum time almost in half. The reasons being are 1) I didn't have to move all the dining chairs around to get under them and the tables and 2) that roller ball cut down on the 'back and forth' motion required to get around a tight corner of a coffee table, couch, or ottoman.  HUGE DIFFERENCE!  I've got a dinosaur Hoover upright that works really well but it takes almost 2 hrs. to vacuum a 1900 sf single story house and it's so loud I feel closer and closer to a hearing aid each day I use it. By spending the difference between a loud Hoover and a quiet and fast Dyson, I figure I'm saving money by not needing the hearing aid so soon. I'm going shopping today for my Dyson DC25 Animal!

Whoever designed this thing probably never vacuums. Yes it will pick up dog hair and fine objects but try anything larger and you might as well bend over and pick it up yourself. Small leaves that drop from my house plants always pose a huge problem for this machine. Not to mention the totally stupid way you have to use the attachments with a really poorly designed scheme. BTW you might as well leave the attachments were they drop since you will be putting them back every few minutes otherwise. They are not at all secured on this unit.Overall I felt like a sucker buying this for almost six hundred bucks. The power cable is one of the cheapest I have seen on a cleaner let alone one that sells for this kind of money. Bottom line this is a $250 vacuum.

For the last few years we always thought we should by the Dyson but we never did. We bought cheaper vacuum cleaners and both of them broke after a while. Both were very hard to maneuver and I am so frustrated that we did not buy the Dyson earlier. The Dyson DC25 is awesome, it is so extremely easy to push, it is light, picks up stuff a lot better and is much easier to clean. I love the little brush that comes with it that is powered by the air it sucks in. It is so easy now to get cat hair of our microfiber couch, it is unbelievable. Before I had to go over the couch 10 times and the hair would still not come of, I had to pick individual hair off with my fingers many times. Now with this little handy brush everything is coming off very easily. I love the Dyson DC25 and can recommend it to everybody.

I wish I had purchased a Dyson Vac a long time ago.  This was my first.  I have 1 cat and 1 dog.  The Animal Vac is great.  It actually gets hair from places that my old Hoover would not even pick up.  The ball technology takes a little getting used to but once you get used to it, it is easy to use.  This vacuum is easy for me to carrier up & down stairs which I was having a problem with.  Would buy again in a heartbeat.

Oh wow.  I had no idea.  I've been using a dirt devil for years, but realized it wasn't really doing a good enough job picking up the pet hair from my 1-year old pup (even though I always first use a 'rug rake' and vacuum about once a week).  As soon as I got it out of the box and click-click-click put it together, I turned it on and gave it a run around my 8'x10' oriental carpet.  It was shocking how much dirt and hair it picked up that my other vacuum left behind.  I'm uploading a photo of the canister - HALF full of hair/dirt/dust/grossness.  I almost died realizing all that stuff has been there all along.  My rug looks like it's been professionally cleaned.  Had no issues with packaging, the refurbished vacuum looked brand new like maybe the 'ball' had been wheeled around a floor a couple times, but totally perfectly clean canister and nothing else looked touched.  Impressed!

I LOVE this vaccuum.  It has cut down the time it takes me to vaccuum my house by more than 50%. I think that is because I only have to run over dirt and hair once and it is picked up. That and switching between carpet beater to hard floor to hose/extension tools is very easy. Everything about it is easy; it is easy to move, with handles that are handy, easy to empty, easy to store. And quiet.I bought mine refurbished, because I was afraid of the large price tag but knowing that once I vaccuum my house it is CLEAN, I would be willing to pay the full price. And I have one dog, two long haired cats, plus a parrot and a little bird, so that's a lot of hair and feathers and little bits of chow to clean up. And dust. Lots and lots of dust from them...I can only remember two negative things I read in reviews before I made my purchase. They were rather minor. One was that the cord doesn't retract. Well, no big deal there, I notice to use the hose you have to unwind the cord completely and drop it to the floor. Since I use the hose after I've cleaned the floor, the floor's clean, so no problem. The other was about having trouble picking up larger bits of detritus off the floor. Tip the vaccuum back more so the front comes up and voila, large bit of dogfood vaccuumed away!  Or you could get out your hose attachment... One thing I noticed myself that was a little different is that the increased suction makes it so I have to use a bit more muscle when using the hose attachment. I feel that it's worthwhile considering how much cleaner and faster the vaccuming goes. Besides, it is a lot lighter than my old vaccuum, so my arms aren't all tired from pushing it around the floor.Like I said, I LOVE this vaccuum. And I HATE housework. So I really LOVE this vaccuum.

This vacuum works great for me(knock on wood)!  I wanted a vacuum that would pick up all the dog hair on our area rug, and it does! I am very happy with it. It was easy to 'assemble'.  I would definitly recommend this vacuum! I bought it refurbished and I HEARD the FedEx guy THROW it in front of my door.  Well, it was packaged GREAT and securely.Oh yes, I did forget to mention -- the hose is very tight, so when you try to use the attachments, it is very difficult because the hose will BARELY extend.  Therefore it is nearly impossible to vacuum blinds or anything that requires you to extend the hose.  Also, I don't find it to work well on our hard floors.I like this vacuum because we have mainly carpet -- and a one-story apartment.  If you have stairs, or mainly hard floors to vacuum, you might consider a different brand.

I purchased the Dyson DC25 November 2011 as our main vacuum since we have a dog. Like most others, I was really impressed with the vacuum. Its lightweight, easy to clean, and it did a good job at picking hair / dirt up -- at least I thought.  Randomly, the other day a guy came by the house selling a Kirby vacuum and I thought, sure, come on in and demo the thing and I'll pat myself on the back for paying 500 dollars for my vacuum.  Let me tell you, a Kirby put my new Dyson to shame.. absolutely no contest. I was shocked at the amount of dirt / hair the Kirby was picking up (and he had me vacuum the house before he used the Kirby). At first I thought it was a total gimmick but it was impossible because he was using new filter pads every 2 swipes and the amount of dirt coming out of the carpet was embarrassing. Long story short, the Dyson (my vacuum) is pretty looking and it does a decent job but it really isn't that good of a vacuum after comparing it to a Kirby.  Now when I see the Dyson commercials on TV I chuckle - its true they never lose suction but it was never that great to begin with.

The vacuum is TOO heavy, it doesn't move easy at all. The extension tubes with brushes are not flexible at all; to clean the stairs I have to carry this gigantic vacuum up and down, every time i use this overpriced and overrated machine I hurt my back. In addition, I think it's a false advetisment about being hypoallergenic: every time I have to empty the canister, I am forced to breath the dust and dirt from it and hands are covered in dust and dirt, I can taste and smell dirt every time I empty the canister. Never again!  next time I will buy german made Muelle. Thanks.

Well where do I start. I have owned Kirby's, Hoover's, Bissel's Oreck and now after months of nagging from my wife I bought her a Dyson for Christmas. I truly believe these are the most overrated vacuums I have ever seen. First the unit just feels cheap and when releasing the wheels to roll the ball it always feels like its gonna break. My wife insisted on the Dyson because it has a hose built in. The hose is the most ridiculous awkward thing on the vacuum.  When you pull it out the handle comes with it and the straight tube make for a very difficult thing to use due to the rigidity of the design. You can remove the handle and just use the flexible portion but then it is so short you have to pick up the entire unit to reach high places. I believe the ball is in the design since the vacuum is so heavy you need the ball to maneuver it. The cord is so short you have to keep unplugging to get from area to area, even 5 feet would make a huge difference. I still own the two Oreck's I purchased years ago and I think they are far better easy to use vacuum which picks up better. I even did a side by side test with my wife and she finally agreed that I was right. I got a free hand held vacuum when I purchased the Oreck and it does a fantastic job but you have to go get it and use it. I could think of the $500 I could have saved and just keep using my Oreck. It also has a fairly large footprint so when storing the unit we can no longer put in a hall closet we have to put out in the garage.  My wife is happy and she can use it all she wants I will get the Oreck out and clean up fast efficient and has very few Plastic parts to go wrong!

I had a Dyson DC07 for a number of years and just loved it!  After it began to fail a little bit in the cleaning department I decided I would treat myself to a new one.  I purchased the DC25 and have hated it from the time I first vacuumed with it and am kicking myself for not returning it for a refund.  I just thought that I needed a little time to adjust to it and it would be fine.  The first problem that is a big one for me is the cord is VERY short.  My old Dyson could vacuum my house with the change of one plug, this one was four times just to move from room to room or you will come up short and not be able to finish the room that you are in!  The second problem is the release on the vacuum I almost have to stomp on it to get it to release and then come just short of flipping the vacuum over to get it to catch in the upright position.  The canister on this one is much smaller than my old one and does not move the carpet, as I like to see the lines on the floor, the head of this one just bounces along the top of the carpet.  I am selling it and have already purchased a new Hoover, that was rated very high on consumer reports and I love it and it has a light on the front!!  That is one feature that Dyson does not offer on any vacuum that I am aware of.

column7: Good but not better than a Hoover
column8: I have had the Dyson for 1 1/2 years and have been happy with it's ability to pick up dog hair and clean my carpets.  Probably the best part about this vac is that it is lightweight in comparison to others and maneuvers very easily around corners and around and under chairs.  Since the main point of a vac is to clean your carpets and floors, I must admit that I don't feel it does any better job than my Hoover Windtunnel I had before the Dyson.  I had my Hover for 5 years, and finally got rid of it when it needed a new belt.  I am pleased by my Dyson, but I do have to empty the bin a lot, like three times per room.  However, this could be due to the fact that I have two large dogs that shed.  I would recommend this vac to others, but I also would happily recommend the Hoover Windtunnel, too.  I am still not convinced the extra money spent on this is worth it.

I love that product. Took me a while to decide on spending the money on that particular brand since is so many different choices on the market today. Is light weight so carry up the stairs is no problem. The kids can use it  with out ' complaining . They love the ball and easy maneuvering around. They think vacuuming is fun. ( one way to make them help).  Yes the bin get full relatively fast, but I did ignored  several times the recommended level of fullness and  continue to vacuum  with out loosing the suction power. Animals short  hair like the Great Dane that we have is no problem to be picked up by this vacuum. Great for dry crumbs in the kitchen.  I will recommend that particular  vacuum  if you short on storage space and not to strong to carry large vacuum around.

Well - I guess I am in the minority here. But - we have a two story house (stairs) with pets (hair) and carpet and hardwood. While I do not deny the suction ability - it is the most awkward when trying to use the hand tools or suction hose by itself. Forget about trying to manipulate it on the stairs, too. Found myself using our wet dry vac for hard to reach areas rather than wrestle with the cumbersome vaccum cleaner. Save yourself a lot of $$$ and buy a regular old canister vac. We have one now and it is so much easier to use.

Save your money.  I purchased this vacuum a month ago from Khols.  Even though I didn't purchase it from Amazon, I bought it based on the recommendations from this site, so I felt it necessary to report back. So I bought it, assembled it, and used it 4 whole times and it BROKE! I don't know what happended.  I called dyson and the rep had me take a couple things apart to look for anythig clogging the machine and there was nothing to be found.  From what I can determine, something in the 'ball' broke.  When I turned it on, it made this sick sounding noise and then when I went to push it, it just locked up. I have an average sized home and I like to think I am very 'gentle' with my tools, especially when they cost nearly $600.00. Anyways, the rep informed me that I can take it to a company in my area to have it seviced.  I informed her that I wouldn't be doing that and that I was going to return it where I purchased it.  Something this expensive shouldn't break after 4 uses! I didn't give up on Dyson, yet.  I bought the DC 14 (no ball).  It's not as easy to use ( a little heavier and a little harder to push), but so far it's working well and from what I can tell, cleanig just as effectively.

Absolutely awesome product!  Cleans better than anything I have ever seen.Very easy to use and no fooling with replacement filters or bags. I would recommend this vacuum cleaner to all, whether you own a pet or not!!

I have only had it a month or so, but it is incredible. I thought my last vacuum was picking up everything, and was I mistaken. The first day I used it, I filled the container in each room that I vacuummed (right after I ran my old vacuum). That sold me!!!!
This is my first upright and I'm amazed at the dirt it picks up!  I'm a little concerned the extending hose isn't going to last too long but time will tell.  I'd buy it again.
Great vacuum that turns on a dime. Great for animal hair - we have three!

I have pets and vacuum everyday and am very pleased with the quality of this vacuum.  The only thing I would change, is the wand is too long to maneuver to clean the inside of the car.  Overall I'm vary satisfied.

column7: Great Buy Dyson DC25 Animal Ball-Technology Upright Vacuum Cleaner
column8: I was a little concerned about an expensive vacuum being that it was only my second vacuum to purchase but, so far it has been well worth the expense.  Not only does my carpet look cleaner it feels cleaner as well.  The mini turbine head was worth the extra expense.  Shipping was fast and product was in great shape.

column7: This vacuum is a must for animal lovers!
column8: My husband and I have been looking and looking at the Dyson Animal vacuum's since they came out.  We just could not get past the sticker shock!  Being animals lovers, we have pet hair in our house.  It was just getting to the point that we could not keep up with our older vacuum.  Again, I used a 20% off coupon from Bed Bath and Beyond and made this purchase finally a reality.  All we could do was say WOW when we got it home and used it on our own carpet.  The whole family was addicted to it for weeks.  We just could not believe how well this machine works.  Love that it's light, easy to move and small enough to store away easily.  It is worth every PENNY we paid and more.

The Animal Ball is much better than the Animal regular vacuum. It is easier to maneuver, easier to clean, lighter, and seems to pickup dirt and hair as good as or better than the regular. It also gets under furniture better. There are only 2 drawbacks that I have noticed - One: The electric cord is about 25 to 30 percent shorter than before so you have to change plugs more frequently. Two: The ball is a little more noisy than the regular .... No deal breaker but definitely louder.

column7: Finally a vacuum that sucks (like it is supposed to!)
column8: The Dyson DC25 Animal performs as advertised.  It is a challenge to use the hand tools however.  The hose is so rigid and the wand so long, it is a bit clumsey.  The directions for how to even use the wand couldn't be found, so we hacked our way into finding the correct buttons and tugging and pulling actions.  I love the way the canister gets emptied.
